{{other uses|In God We Trust (disambiguation)}} [[File:1in god we trust.jpg|thumb|"IN GOD WE TRUST" on the reverse of a [[United States twenty-dollar bill]]]] [[File:Flag_of_Florida.svg|thumb|"IN GOD WE TRUST" on the [[Flag of Florida]]]]
"'''In God We Trust'''" is the [[United States national motto|official motto]] of the [[United States|United States of America]], [[Nicaragua]], and of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Florida]]. It was adopted as the nation's motto in 1956 as a replacement or alternative to the unofficial motto of ''[[E pluribus unum]]'', which was adopted when the [[Great Seal of the United States]] was created and adopted in 1782.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CxtVAAAAYAAJ&q=In+1956,+an+official+national+motto+was+adopted,+%22In+God+We+Trust,%22+replacing+the+unofficial+%22E+Pluribus+Unum.%22&dq=In+1956,+an+official+national+motto+was+adopted,+%22In+God+We+Trust,%22+replacing+the+unofficial+%22E+Pluribus+Unum.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BGKsadjbfausdghasudghflasgdihasl;rghawuilrgfarhuglarhugzaehgl%20iuhalrighuafT4q_IKfj0QGWg6n_AQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA|title=Annual report – American Civil Liberties Union, Volume 5|year=1951|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|quote=In 1956, an official national motto was adopted, "In God We Trust," replacing the unofficial "E Pluribus Unum."|accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6lrAmPlbvIC&pg=PA79&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Refiguring Mass Communication: A History|date=24 March 2010|publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]]|quote=He held high the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the nation's unofficial motto, ''e pluribus unum'', even as he was recoiling from the party system in which he had long participated.|accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref>
"In God We Trust" first appeared on the [[Two-cent piece (United States)|two-cent piece]] in 1864<ref name="USTreasury">{{cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/about/education/Pages/in-god-we-trust.aspx|title=History of 'In God We Trust'|last=U.S. Department of the Treasury|first=|date=2011|website=www.treasury.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-14}}</ref> and has appeared on [[Federal Reserve Note|paper currency]] since 1957. A law passed in a Joint Resolution by the 84th Congress (P.L. 84-140) and approved by President [[Dwight Eisenhower]] on July 30, 1956, declared "In God We Trust" must appear on American currency. This phrase was first used on paper money in 1957, when it appeared on the one-dollar silver certificate. The first paper currency bearing the phrase entered circulation on October 1, 1957.<ref name="USTreasury"/> The 84th Congress later passed legislation (P.L. 84-851), also signed by President Eisenhower on July 30, 1956, declaring the phrase to be the national motto.<ref>{{USC|36|302}} ''National motto''</ref><ref name="USTFS">{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/about/education/Pages/in-god-we-trust.aspx|title=U.S. on the History of "In God We Trust"|publisher=United States Department of the Treasury|accessdate=2009-04-22}}</ref><ref name="USPL84-851">[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-70/pdf/STATUTE-70-Pg732-2.pdf United States Public Law 84-851], United States Public Law 84-851.</ref>
Some groups and people have expressed objections to its use, citing its religious reference that violates the [[Establishment Clause]] of the [[First Amendment]].<ref>{{cite news|author=12 Mar 2010 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/7426824/Atheist-in-battle-to-remove-In-God-We-Trust-from-US-currency.html |title=Atheist in battle to remove 'In God We Trust' from US currency |publisher=Telegraph |date=2010-03-12 |accessdate=2014-02-04 |location=London}}</ref> These groups believe the phrase should be removed from currency and public property. In lawsuits, this argument has so far not overcome the interpretational doctrine of [[accommodationism]], which allows government to endorse religious establishments as long as they are all treated equally.<ref name="Drakeman1991">{{cite book|last=Drakeman|first=Donald L.|title=Church-state Constitutional Issues: Making Sense of the Establishment Clause|date=1 January 1991|publisher=Greenwood Press|language=English |isbn=9780313276637}}</ref> According to a 2003 joint poll by [[USA Today]], [[CNN]], and [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]], 90% of Americans support the inscription "In God We Trust" on U.S. coins.<ref name=Poll>{{cite news|title=USA TODAY/CNN/Gallup Poll results|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/polls/tables/live/2003-09-29-religion-poll.htm|quote=C. The inscription "In God We Trust" on U.S. coins; 2003 Sep 19–21; Approve 90; Disapprove 8; No opinion 2|publisher=[[USA Today]]|year=2011|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2006, "In God We Trust" was designated as the motto of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Florida]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.netstate.com/states/mottoes/fl_motto.htm|title=Florida State Motto In God We Trust|first=NSTATE, LLC:|last=http://www.n-state.com|date=|website=www.netstate.com}}</ref><ref name="myflorida.com">{{cite web|url=http://dos.myflorida.com/florida-facts/florida-state-symbols/state-motto/|title=State Motto – Florida Department of State|author=|date=|website=dos.myflorida.com}}</ref> Its [[Spanish language|Spanish]] equivalent, ''En Dios Confiamos,'' is the motto of the [[Nicaragua|Republic of Nicaragua]].<ref>As shown on the [[Nicaraguan córdoba|Córdoba]] (bank notes and coins); see for example [http://bcn.gob.ni/billetes_monedas/index.html?&val=1 Banco Central de Nicaragua] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506010635/http://www.bcn.gob.ni/billetes_monedas/index.html |date=2012-05-06 }}</ref>
==History== [[File:Chase to Pollock 1863-12-09 motto only.png|thumb|[[Salmon P. Chase|Salmon P. Chase, Treasury Secretary]], scribes "In God is Our Trust," scratches out "is Our" and overwrites "We" to arrive at "In God We Trust" in a December 9, 1863, letter to [[James Pollock]], Director of the Philadelphia Mint.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chase|first=Salmon P|title=Letter to James Pollock|publisher=National Archives and Records Administration|work=Document # RG 104_UD 87-A_Folder In God We Trust 1861_Part1|page=11|date=December 9, 1863}}</ref>|left]] [[File:1864_2C_Small_Motto_Red_(obv).jpg|thumb|"{{sc|IN GOD WE TRUST}}" first appeared on the obverse side of the [[Two-cent piece (United States)|Two-cent piece]] in 1864<ref name="USTreasury"/>|left]] In 1860, the phrase was used in the [[Coat of arms of New Westminster]], Canada. The phrase has been included in many hymns and religious-patriotic songs. During the [[American Civil War]], the [[125th Pennsylvania Infantry]] for the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] [[Union Army|Army]] assumed the motto "In God we trust" in early August 1862.<ref>{{cite book|last=The Regimental Committee|first=125th PA Volunteers, 1862–1863|title=Regimental History|year=2009|publisher=Cornell University Library|location=Ithaca, NY|isbn=978-1-112-13570-5|pages=150–152}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Alexander|first=ted|title=The Battle of Antietam|year=2011|publisher=The History Press|location=Charleston, SC|isbn=978-1-60949-179-6|page=76}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLc6WDOMUwA|title=125th PA Vol. Infantry: IN GOD WE TRUST|date=28 June 2012|work=YouTube}}</ref> William W. Wallace, coiner, circa August 1862, of the motto "In God We Trust"{{sfn| Regimental Committee| 1906|p=151}} was Captain of Company C of the 125th Pennsylvania Infantry.
The Reverend [[Mark R. Watkinson]] of '[[Ridleyville]]', [[Pennsylvania]], (pastor of Prospect Hill Baptist Church in present-day [[Prospect Park, Pennsylvania]]) in a letter dated November 13, 1861, petitioned the Treasury Department to add a statement recognizing "[[Almighty God]] in some form on our coins" in order to "relieve us from the ignominy of heathenism".<ref name=Treasury>{{cite web|title=History of 'In God We Trust'|url=http://www.treasury.gov/about/education/Pages/in-god-we-trust.aspx|publisher=U.S. Department of the Treasury|accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="US-CSS">United States (1897). ''Congressional Serial Set''. US: Government Printing Office, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Yv0qAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA260 p. 260.]</ref> At least part of the motivation was to declare that [[God]] was on the Union side of the [[American Civil War|Civil War.]]<ref name="history">{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/about/education/Pages/in-god-we-trust.aspx|title=History of 'In God We Trust'|work=treasury.gov|accessdate=2016-04-29}}</ref> Treasury Secretary [[Salmon P. Chase]] acted on this proposal and directed the then-Philadelphia [[Director of the United States Mint|Director of the Mint]], [[James Pollock]], to begin drawing up possible designs that would include the religious phrase. Chase chose his favorite designs and presented a proposal to Congress for the new designs in late 1863.<ref>Duncan, Ann W. (2008). [https://books.google.com/books?id=zzOn09EaETgC&pg=PA63 Religion, Rhetoric, and Ritual in the U.S. Government,"] ''Church-state Issues in America Today''. Westport CT: Greenwood Publishing Group, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zzOn09EaETgC&pg=PA77 pp. 77.]</ref>
In December 1863, [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s Secretary of the Treasury decided on a new motto, "In God We Trust," to engrave on U.S. coins. Lincoln's involvement in this decision is unclear.<ref>According to The ''Congressional Record'' (1908, House), p. 3387, the motto was adopted "doubtless with his [Lincoln's] knowledge and approval." </ref>
A version of the motto made an early appearance on obverse side of the [[Interest bearing note#Denominational set of interest bearing notes|twenty dollar interest bearing note]] issued in 1864 along with the motto "God and our Right".
As Chase was preparing his recommendation to Congress, it was found that the Act of Congress dated January 18, 1837 prescribed the mottoes and devices that should be placed upon the coins of the United States. This meant that the mint could make no changes without the enactment of additional legislation by the Congress. Such legislation was introduced and passed as the [[Coinage Act of 1864]] on April 22, 1864, allowing the Secretary of the Treasury to authorize the inclusion of the phrase on one-cent and two-cent coins.<ref name="history" />
An Act of Congress passed on March 3, 1865, allowed the Mint Director, with the Secretary's approval, to place the motto on all gold and silver coins that "shall admit the inscription thereon".<ref name="history" /><ref name=CR1956p13917>[http://www.nonbeliever.org/images/CR102-13917.pdf ''Congressional Record'', 1956, p. 13917], via NonBeliever.org</ref> In 1873, Congress passed the Coinage Act, granting that the Secretary of the Treasury "may cause the motto IN GOD WE TRUST to be inscribed on such coins as shall admit of such motto".
The similar phrase 'In God is our Trust' appears in "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]", adopted as the national anthem of the United States in 1931. Written by [[Francis Scott Key]] during the [[War of 1812]], the fourth stanza includes the phrase, "And this be our motto: 'In God is our Trust'", which was adapted as the national motto.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://time.com/4179685/in-god-we-trust-currency-history/ |title=How 'In God We Trust' Got on the Currency in the First Place |first=Sarah |last=Begley |magazine=Time |date=January 13, 2016 |access-date=February 24, 2018 }}</ref>{{better source|reason=We have one 2016 article that mentions this supposed concious adaptation, but are there any other secondary sources that make this claim? For instance, are there any mentions of this connection from 1863, 1931 or 1956? Or maybe a later scholarly analysis of the motto?|date=March 2018}}
The use of "In God We Trust" has been interrupted. The motto disappeared from the five-cent coin in 1883, and did not reappear until production of the Jefferson nickel began in 1938.<ref name="history"/> However, at least two other coins minted in every year in the interim still bore the motto,{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} including the [[Morgan dollar]] and the [[United States Seated Liberty coinage|Seated Liberty half dollar]]. The omission of the motto "In God We Trust" on the [[Indian Head eagle]] coin caused public outrage, and prompted [[United States Congress|Congress]] to pass a bill mandating its inclusion. Mint Chief Engraver [[Charles E. Barber]] added the words and made minor modifications to the design. In 1908, Congress made it mandatory that the phrase be printed on all coins upon which it had previously appeared. This decision was motivated after a public outcry following the release of a $20 coin which did not bear the motto.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.republicanpresidents.net/10-interesting-facts-about-theodore-roosevelt/ |title=10 Interesting Facts About Theodore Roosevelt |publisher=Republicanpresidents.net |date= |accessdate=2014-02-04}}</ref> The motto has been in continuous use on the one-cent coin since 1909, and on the ten-cent coin since 1916. It also has appeared on all gold coins and silver dollar coins, half-dollar coins, and quarter-dollar coins struck since July 1, 1908.<ref name="history"/> Since 1938, all US coins have borne the motto.<ref name="USTreasury"/> [[File:2014 ATB Quarter Obv.png|thumb|left|A [[quarter dollar]] with the United States' official motto "{{sc|IN GOD WE TRUST}}" on the obverse side]]
During the [[Cold War]] era, the government of the United States sought to distinguish itself from the [[Soviet Union]], which promoted [[state atheism]] and thus implemented [[Soviet anti-religious legislation|antireligious legislation]].<ref>Merriman, Scott A. [https://books.google.com/books?id=l_8VFygyaDYC&pg=PA281&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false Religion and the Law in America: An Encyclopedia of Personal Belief and Public Policy]. Santa Barbara, CA: ABC-CLIO, 2007. Print. "In 1956, the United States, changed its motto to "In God We Trust," in large part to differentiate itself from the Soviet Union, its Cold War enemy that was widely seen as promoting atheism."</ref> The [[84th United States Congress|84th Congress]] passed a joint resolution "declaring IN GOD WE TRUST the national motto of the United States". The resolution passed both the House and the Senate unanimously and without debate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/249484657/?terms=in+god+we+trust|title=New National Motto Of U. S. Recalls Key's Words Of 1814| date=13 Aug 1956|page=8|work=[[Palladium-Item]]|location=Richmond, Indiana|via=Newspapers.com|access-date=2018-02-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>Miller, Douglas and Nowak, Marion'', The Fifties: The Way We Really Were''. 1977, 89. "'In God We Trust' was adopted as the national motto in 1956, with neither debate nor a single dissenting vote in the House or Senate."</ref> The law was signed by President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]] on July 30, 1956.<ref>[[s:Public Law 84-851|Public Law 84-851]]</ref> The United States Code at {{USC|36|302}}, now states: "'In God we trust' is the national motto."
The same day, the President signed into law<ref>[[s:Public Law 84-140|Public Law 84-140]]</ref> a requirement that "In God We Trust" be printed on all U.S. currency and coins. On paper currency, it first appeared on the [[Silver certificate (United States)|silver certificate]] in 1957, followed by other certificates. [[Federal Reserve Note]]s and [[United States Note]]s were circulated with the motto starting from 1964 to 1966, depending on the denomination.<ref name="history"/><ref>Steven B. Epstein, "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1123418 Rethinking the Constitutionality of Ceremonial Deism]" Columbia Law Review, Vol. 96, No. 8. (Dec., 1996), p. 2083–2174, quoting the [[peroration]] (abridged here) of the speech by [[Charles Edward Bennett]], sponsor in the House, the only speech in either House of Congress on the subject. President Eisenhower and [[W. Randolph Burgess]], Deputy to the [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Treasury for Monetary Affairs]], had approved of the legislation! 101 [[Congressional Record]] pp. 4384 (quoted), 7796. (1955)</ref> (Of these, only Federal Reserve Notes are still circulated.)
Representative [[Charles Edward Bennett]] of Florida cited the Cold War when he introduced the bill in the House, saying "In these days when imperialistic and materialistic communism seeks to attack and destroy freedom, we should continually look for ways to strengthen the foundations of our freedom". <ref>{{cite web|url=http://history.house.gov/Historical-Highlights/1951-2000/The-legislation-placing-%E2%80%9CIn-God-We-Trust%E2%80%9D-on-national-currency/ |title=The legislation placing "In God We Trust" on national currency | US House of Representatives: History, Art & Archives |publisher=history.house.gov |date=1955-07-11 |accessdate=2017-05-13}}</ref>
[[Aronow v. United States]] was the first case to challenge the inclusion of "In God We Trust" on [[United States dollar|U.S. currency]].<ref name="AronowUS">{{cite court |litigants=Aronow v. United States |vol=432 |no=23444 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=242 |pinpoint=243 |court=9th Cir. |date=October 6, 1970 |url=http://openjurist.org/432/f2d/242/aronow-v-united-states}}</ref> The law it challenged was "31 U.S.C. § 324a "the inscription 'In God we Trust'...shall appear on all United States currency and coins".<ref name="AronowUS"/> O'Hair v. Blumenthal (1978) challenged the inclusion of the phrase "In God We Trust" on U.S. currency. A similar decision was reached by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|Fifth Circuit]] in [[Madalyn Murray O'Hair]] vs [[W. Michael Blumenthal]] in 1979, which affirmed that the "primary purpose of the slogan was secular."<ref name="Duncan">Duncan, Ann W. (2008). ''Church-state Issues in America Today''. Westport CT: Greenwood Publishing Group, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zzOn09EaETgC&pg=PA88 p. 88.]</ref>
In March 2001, [[Governor of Mississippi]] [[Ronnie Musgrove]] signed legislation requiring the motto "In God We Trust" to be displayed in every [[Public school (government funded)|public school]] classroom, as well as the school auditoriums and cafeterias, throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pfaw.org/pfaw/general/default.aspx?oid=3643|title=Page not found|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807082223/http://www.pfaw.org/pfaw/general/default.aspx?oid=3643|archivedate=7 August 2007|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/25/us/national-news-briefs-in-god-we-trust-motto-for-mississippi-schools.html|title=National News Briefs; 'In God We Trust' Motto For Mississippi Schools|first=The Associated|last=Press|date=25 March 2001|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
[[File:In God We Trust AFA Poster in New Philadelphia High School.jpg|thumb|A framed poster displaying the national motto of the United States in a [[New Philadelphia High School]] classroom]] After the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001, many public schools across the United States posted "In God We Trust" framed posters in their "libraries, cafeterias and classrooms". The [[American Family Association]] supplied several 11-by-14-inch posters to school systems and vowed to defend any legal challenges to the displaying of the posters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/02/20/usat-posters.htm|title=USATODAY.com – 'In God We Trust' pressed for schools|work=usatoday.com | date=19 February 2002}}</ref>
According to a 2003 joint poll by ''[[USA Today]]'', [[CNN]], and [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]], 90% of Americans support the inscription "In God We Trust" on U.S. coins.<ref name=Poll/>
In 2006, on the 50th anniversary of its adoption, the [[United States Senate|Senate]] reaffirmed "In God We Trust" as the official national motto of the United States of America.<ref name=Senate>{{cite news|author=Felicia Sonmez|title=Social issues return to fore with 'In God We Trust' resolution|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/post/social-issues-return-to-fore-with-in-god-we-trust-resolution/2011/10/31/gIQAXQasZM_blog.html|quote="In 2006, on the 50th anniversary of its adoption, the Senate reaffirmed 'In God We Trust' as the official national motto of the United States," Forbes said in a statement announcing the vote. "Tomorrow, the House of Representatives will have the same opportunity to reaffirm our national motto and directly confront a disturbing trend of inaccuracies and omissions, misunderstandings of church and state, rogue court challenges, and efforts to remove God from the public domain by unelected bureaucrats."|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=7 November 2011|date=1 November 2011}}</ref> In Florida House Bill no. 1145, Florida adopted 'In God We Trust' as the official state motto, effective July 1, 2006.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="myflorida.com"/>
In 2011 the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] passed an additional resolution reaffirming "In God We Trust" as the official motto of the United States, in a 396–9 vote.<ref name=Reaffirm>{{cite news|author=Jennifer Steinhauer|title=In God We Trust, With the House's Help|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/02/us/house-of-representatives-affirms-in-god-we-trust-motto.html|quote= Citing a crisis of national identity and mass confusion among Americans about their nation's motto, the House on Tuesday voted on a resolution "reaffirming 'In God We Trust' as the official motto of the United States."|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=7 November 2011|date=3 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Iqraar>{{cite news|author=Todd Starnes|title=See Which Congressmen Voted Against 'In God We Trust'|url=http://nation.foxnews.com/congress/2011/11/01/see-which-congressmen-voted-against-god-we-trust#ixzz1cYiMXHil|quote=The House of Representatives passed a bi-partisan resolution Tuesday night reaffirming "In God We Trust" as the official motto of the United States. The 396–9 vote came at the request of Rep. Randy Forbes (R-VA).|publisher=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=7 November 2011|date=3 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2013, a federal court rejected a challenge, brought by [[Michael Newdow]] and the [[Freedom From Religion Foundation]], to remove "In God We Trust" from American currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ksl.com/index.php?nid=1016&sid=26823999&fm=most_popular|title=Lawsuit to remove 'In God We Trust' from money gets dismissed - KSL.com|work=ksl.com}}</ref>
[[File:Seal_of_Mississippi_(2014-present).svg|thumb|"{{sc|IN GOD WE TRUST}}" on the [[Seal of Mississippi]]|left]] On January 31, 2014, purporting to defend religious freedom, the [[Mississippi]] senate voted to add the words, "In God We Trust" to the state seal and the change was made effective on July 1, 2014.<ref name=2014Seal>{{cite web|url=http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/documents/2014/pdf/SB/2600-2699/SB2681PS.pdf |title=Mississippi Religious Freedom Restoration Act; enact and modify the great seal. |work=Senate Bill No. 2681 |date=January 2014 |author=Mississippi Legislature |publisher=State of Mississippi |location=Mississippi |accessdate=April 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140402134106/http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/documents/2014/pdf/SB/2600-2699/SB2681PS.pdf |archivedate=April 2, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wagster Pettus |first=Emily |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Miss. Senate OKs adding 'In God We Trust' to seal |work= |publisher=WorldNow and WLBT |date=31 January 2014 |url=http://www.msnewsnow.com/story/24601213/miss-senate-oks-adding-in-god-we-trust-to-seal |doi= |accessdate=1 February 2014 }}{{dead link|date=August 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 2015 the county police department of [[Jefferson County, Illinois]] announced that the words "In God We Trust" will be on police squad cars.<ref>"[http://www.kfvs12.com/story/29683669/in-god-we-trust-to-be-placed-on-jefferson-co-il-squad-cars 'In God We Trust' to be placed on Jefferson Co., IL squad cars]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6aSm61nMB?url=http://web.archive.org/web/20150801181841/http://www.kfvs12.com/story/29683669/in-god-we-trust-to-be-placed-on-jefferson-co-il-squad-cars Archive]). ''[[KFVS]]''. August 1, 2015. Retrieved on August 2, 2015.</ref> In 2015, the Freedom from Religion Foundation demanded that local authorities remove decals of the motto from Childress, Texas Police Department patrol vehicles. In response, Police Chief Adrian Garcia told the organization, in a written letter, to "go fly a kite."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailysignal.com/2015/10/01/atheist-group-calls-for-removal-of-in-god-we-trust-police-car-decals-police-chief-says-go-fly-a-kite/|title=Atheist Group Asks Police Remove 'In God We Trust' Car Decal|author=|date=|website=dailysignal.com}}</ref>
In March 2017, Act 911, sponsored by State Rep. [[Jim Dotson]], made it a requirement of [[Arkansas]] state law for schools to display posters with the national motto ("In God We Trust").<ref>http://insider.foxnews.com/2018/03/12/god-we-trust-posters-be-displayed-arkansas-public-schools-after-donations</ref><ref>http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2018/mar/11/schools-will-display-in-god-we-trust-20/</ref>
In early 2018, [[Kimberly Daniels]], a [[pastor]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://charismanews.com/us/64103-apostle-kimberly-daniels-scores-big-win-for-prayer-in-public-schools|title=Apostle Kimberly Daniels Scores Big Win for Prayer in Public Schools|first=Charlene Aaron/CBN|last=News|date=|website=charismanews.com}}</ref> who currently serves as the representative for [[Florida House of Representatives]] District 14 as a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], introduced HB 839, a bill that requires public schools to display the motto "In God We Trust" in a conspicuous place. On Tuesday, January 23, 2018, the bill received unanimous approval from the House PreK-12 Innovation Subcommittee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/florida/fl-reg-in-god-we-trust-schools-20180124-story.html |title=Schools could be required to display 'In God we trust' |publisher=Sun Sentinel |date= |accessdate=2018-03-22}}</ref> Later, in a vote on February 21, 2018, the bill passed 97 to 10 in the House.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/23/us/florida-in-god-we-trust-legislation-trnd/index.html|title=Florida lawmakers advance a bill that requires 'In God We Trust' displayed on school grounds|first=Joe Sterling,|last=CNN|date=|website=cnn.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/florida-lawmakers-give-go-ahead-bill-have-god-we-trust-school-buildings-818745|title=Florida lawmakers advance bill that would require 'In God We Trust' to be visible on all school buildings|author=|date=23 February 2018|website=newsweek.com}}</ref> As part of Florida's March 2018 K-12 education law, Gov. [[Rick Scott]] mandated that all public schools post the state motto ("In God We Trust") in a prominent location.<ref>http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/gradebook/2018/03/26/atheist-group-offers-to-provide-in-god-we-trust-signs-to-florida-public-schools/</ref>
In March 2018, a bill requiring Tennessee schools to prominently display the national motto ("In God We Trust") sponsored by Rep. [[Susan Lynn]] passed the state House with 81 of the 99 members voting in favor of it.<ref>https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/religion/2018/03/21/tennessee-lawmakers-pass-bill-requiring-public-schools-post-god-we-trust-motto/442884002/</ref>
==Society and culture== ===Religion=== In [[Judaism]] and [[Christianity]], the official motto "In God We Trust" resounds with several verses from the [[Bible]], including {{Bibleverse||Proverbs|3:5|KJV}}, {{Bibleverse||Psalm|118:8|KJV}}, {{Bibleverse||Psalm|40:3|KJV}}, {{Bibleverse||Psalm|73:28|KJV}}, and {{Bibleverse||Proverbs|29:25|KJV}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=In God We Trust: The Motto|url=http://www.allabouthistory.org/in-god-we-trust.htm|publisher=All About History|accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> Melkote Ramaswamy, a Hindu American scholar, writes that the presence of the phrase "In God We Trust" on American currency is a reminder that "there is God everywhere, whether we are conscious or not."<ref>{{cite web |last=Ramaswamy |first=Melkote |url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20120811/LIFE04/208110323/In-Hinduism-there-just-one-God-many-forms |title=Faith/Values | Indianapolis Star |publisher=indystar.com |date=2012-08-11 |accessdate=2014-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019115759/http://www.indystar.com/article/20120811/LIFE04/208110323/In-Hinduism-there-just-one-God-many-forms |archivedate=2014-10-19 |df= }}</ref>
===In popular culture=== *In the 1994 film ''[[Miracle on 34th Street (1994 film)|Miracle on 34th Street]]'', just as Henry is about to make his decision, Susan walks up to him with a Christmas card containing a $1 bill. On the back, the words "In God We Trust" are circled. He realizes that, since the U.S. Department of Treasury can put its official faith in God with no hard evidence, then the people can believe in Santa in the same way. Left with no choice, an elated Henry dismisses the case and declares that Santa is real, existing in the person of Kris. * In the musical ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'', Aaron Burr says the line "My God! In God we trust, but we’ll never know what got discussed" in reaction to Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and Alexander Hamilton making a deal.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} * An e-mail conspiracy theory is that "In God We Trust" was intentionally omitted from new U.S. dollar coins in 2007.<ref>"Historic Change", Snopes, http://www.snopes.com/politics/religion/dollarcoin.asp</ref> The first coins produced under the [[Presidential $1 Coin Program]] did indeed lack the "In God We Trust" inscription along their edges (along with the "E Pluribus Unum" inscription, the year of production, and the [[mint mark]]; these coins, unlike normal dollar coins, had completely blank edges), but these coins, known as "[[Presidential $1 Coin Program#Minting errors|godless dollars]]", were the result of a minting error, not a deliberate omission.<ref>{{cite web|author=David S Morgan |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/03/07/national/main2543125.shtml?source=RSSattr=HOME_2543125 |title="Godless" Dollar Coins Slip Through Mint |publisher=CBS News |date=2007-03-07 |accessdate=2010-11-03}}</ref><ref>[http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/070307/godless_dollars.html?.v=3 Associated Press: Dollar Coins Missing 'In God We Trust'], By David S Morgan, (Mar. 7, 2007), CBS News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070319223227/http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/070307/godless_dollars.html?.v=3 |date=March 19, 2007 }}</ref> *[[Marty Feldman]]'s satirical comedy ''[[In God We Tru$t]]'' (1980). *The film ''[[They Live]]'' (1988) plays on the idea. Special sunglasses allow the wearers to see simple hidden messages instead of the signs they see without them. Advertising is seen as "OBEY", "CONSUME" and "MARRY AND REPRODUCE". Dollar bills are all marked "THIS IS YOUR GOD".<ref>{{cite web|last=Rothkopf |first=Joshua |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/features/how-they-live-took-on-the-republicans-and-won-20141027 |title="Empire of the Sunglasses: How 'They Live' Took on Republicans and Won", by Joshua Rothkopf, ''Rolling Stone'' |publisher=Rollingstone.com |date=2014-10-27 |accessdate=2018-03-22}}</ref> *In January 2006, [[Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen]] and his wife Jackie were offered a place on the [[Valentine's Day]] celebrity couples edition of ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' They appeared on the show managing to reach the £1 million question, before answering it incorrectly and dropping from £500,000 all the way down to just £32,000 (a loss of £468,000). For the first time ever, [[Celador]] allowed Llewelyn-Bowen and his wife retry the show after the company claimed that the last question "didn't meet their standards".{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} After returning and being shown a different £1 million question, the couple decided not to risk losing £468,000 for the second time and won £500,000 for their chosen charity, [[Shooting Star Children's Hospice|The Shooting Star Children's Hospice]], of which Llewelyn-Bowen and his wife are both patrons. Their new question was about the first man to travel to space twice, and the correct answer to the question was [[Gus Grissom]]. They decided not to risk it this time and walked away with the £500,000. This amount is the highest amount that any celebrity couple has won on any British edition of ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?''<ref name="secondchance"/> The £468,000 they originally lost was also the ''greatest loss'' ever seen on the show, and no other contestant has ever answered the final question incorrectly in the United Kingdom version.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-373958/Llewelyn-Bowen-blows-1m.html|title=Llewelyn-Bowen blows £1m|publisher=The Daily Mail|first=Matt|last=Born|date=13 January 2006|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2009/08/who-wants-to-be-a-millionaire-ken-basin-harvard-law-08-sure-does/|title=Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Ken Basin, Harvard Law '08, Sure Does|publisher=Above the Law|first=David|last=Lat|date=25 August 2009|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> The allegedly misleading question was "Translated from the [[Latin language|Latin]], what is the motto of the United States?" The answer given was "In God We Trust" which is originally English and has in fact been the motto of the United States since 1956. The intended answer had been "One Out of Many" which is a translation of the Latin phrase ''[[E pluribus unum]]'', which is not actually the current United States motto. ''E pluribus unum'' had been the de facto motto but was never legally declared as such.<ref name="secondchance">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4608690.stm|title=TV designer's second shot at £1m |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=13 January 2006|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref>
===License plates=== [[File:2008 South Carolina license plate In God We Trust 000 000.png|thumb|"{{sc|IN GOD WE TRUST}}" optional [[South Carolina license plates|license plate]] designed by Troy Wingard for the [[South Carolina Department of Public Safety]] in 2002]] {{citation needed span|As of April 1, 2016 the following U.S. states currently offer an "In God We Trust" license plate as a speciality plate for an additional normal vehicle registration processing which vary from state to state: Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, North Carolina, Ohio <ref>http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/4503.763</ref>, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia, and Wisconsin.|date=April 2018}}
{{citation needed span|Florida (Which also offers a speciality plate) and Georgia which both display the county of issuance on their License Plate offer the option of "In God We Trust" in place of the County Name.|date=April 2018}}
==Criticism== Advocates of [[Separation of church and state in the United States|separation of church and state]] have questioned the legality of this motto asserting that it is a violation of the United States Constitution, prohibiting the government from passing any law respecting an establishment of religion.<ref name=Views>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vonnZcMHs8kC&pg=PA60|title=The Dynamic Constitution: an Introduction to Americans Constitutional Law|author=Richard H. Fallon|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|page= 60|quote="Strict separationists" believe that the government has no business supporting religious beliefs or institutions in any way – for example, by providing tax breaks to churches, assisting parochial schools, including prayers or benedictions in public ceremonies, or inscribing "In God We Trust" on the currency. Religious accommodationists can well explain why certain entrenched social practices (such as the inscription of "In God We Trust" on the currency) were not historically perceived as presenting constitutional difficulties: The relevant practices are not coercive and do not prefer one narrow sect over another.|isbn=978-0-521-60078-1|year=2004}}</ref> Religious [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution#Accommodationists|accommodationists]] state that this entrenched practice has not historically presented any constitutional difficulty, is not coercive, and does not prefer one religious denomination over another.<ref name="Views" />
"In God We Trust" as a national motto and on U.S. currency has been the subject of numerous unsuccessful lawsuits.<ref name="AtheistLawsuit">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/29/atheist-lawsuit-currency-god_n_5412890.html |title=Atheists Lose Latest Battle To Remove 'In God We Trust' From U.S. Currency |last1=Markoe |first1=Lauren |date=2014-05-29 |website=huffingtonpost.com |publisher=[[Religion News Service]] |accessdate=2014-10-09}}</ref> The motto was first challenged in ''[[Aronow v. United States]]'' in 1970, but the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] ruled: "It is quite obvious that the national motto and the slogan on coinage and currency 'In God We Trust' has nothing whatsoever to do with the establishment of religion. Its use is of patriotic or ceremonial character and bears no true resemblance to a governmental sponsorship of a religious exercise."<ref>Aronow, 432 F.2d at 243.</ref> In ''[[Lynch v. Donnelly]]'' (1984), the Supreme Court wrote that acts of "[[ceremonial deism]]" are "protected from Establishment Clause scrutiny chiefly because they have lost through rote repetition any significant religious content".<ref>[http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=US&vol=465&invol=668 LYNCH v. DONNELLY, 465 U.S. 668 (1984)] U.S. Supreme Court</ref> In ''[[Zorach v. Clauson]]'' (1952), the Supreme Court also wrote that the nation's "institutions presuppose a Supreme Being" and that government recognition of [[God]] does not constitute the establishment of a state church as the Constitution's authors intended to prohibit.<ref name=ABA>{{cite book|title=ABA Journal Sep 1962|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gymQ6vWfA3QC&pg=PA817&dq=Zorach+v.+Clauson+++In+God+We+Trust#v=onepage&q=Zorach%20v.%20Clauson%20%20%20In%20God%20We%20Trust&f=false|quote=Much more recently, in 1952, speaking through Mr. Justice Douglas in ''Zorach v. Clauson'', 343 U.S. 306, 313, the Supreme Court repeated the same sentiments, saying: We are a religious people whose institutions presuppose a Supreme Being. Mr. Justice Brewer in the ''Holy Trinity'' case, ''supra'', mentioned many of these evidences of religion, and Mr. Justice Douglas in the ''Zorach'' case referred to ... [P]rayers in our legislative halls; the appeals to the Almighty in the messages of the Chief Executive; the proclamation making Thanksgiving Day a holiday; "So help me God" in our courtroom oaths – these and ... other references to the Almighty ... run through our laws, our public rituals, our ceremonies ... the supplication with which the Court opens each session: "God save the United States and this Honorable Court" (312–313). To this list may be added tax exemption of churches, chaplaincies in the armed forces, the "Pray for Peace" postmark, the widespread observance of Christmas holidays, and, in classrooms, singing the fourth stanza of ''America'' which is prayer invoking the protection of God, and the words "in God is our trust" as found in the National Anthem, and the reciting of the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag, modified by an Act of Congress of June 14, 1954, to include the words "under God.}}</ref>
In November 2005, [[Michael Newdow]] announced he wants to have "In God We Trust" removed from [[Coins of the United States dollar|U.S. coins]] and [[Federal Reserve Note|banknotes]]. In 2004, he received the special Recognition Freethought Hero Award for his case to remove "In God We Trust" from currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ffrf.org/awards/special/2004_newdow.php |title=Freethought Hero Award 2004 – Mike Newdow |accessdate=2007-07-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070729192510/http://ffrf.org/awards/special/2004_newdow.php |archivedate=2007-07-29 |df= }}, [[Freedom From Religion Foundation]] 2004-10-30</ref> In a November 14, 2005 interview with [[Fox News]]'s [[Neil Cavuto]], Newdow compared "In God We Trust" appearing on United States currency with [[racial segregation]] (specifically separate drinking fountains), saying, "How can you not compare those? What is the difference there? Both of them [whites and blacks] got equal water. They both had access. It was government saying that it's okay to separate out these two people on the basis of race. Here we're saying it's okay to separate two people on the basis of their religious beliefs."
In June 2006, a federal judge rejected Newdow's Establishment Clause lawsuit on the grounds that the minted words amount to a secular national slogan, and do not dictate anyone's beliefs. Newdow stated that he would appeal the ruling,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,199211,00.html | title=Federal Judge Nixes 'In God We Trust' Lawsuit | publisher=[[Fox News Channel]] | date=2006-06-12}}</ref> although it should be noted that ''[[Aronow v. United States]]'' was decided on the same grounds in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] and the lower court was required to return the same ruling, likewise the Ninth Circuit does not traditionally overrule previous Ninth Circuit rulings.
On December 4, 2007, Newdow argued before a three-judge panel of the Ninth Circuit to remove both "under God" from the Pledge of Allegiance (''Roe v. Rio Linda Union School District''),{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} and "In God We Trust" from United States currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fl1.findlaw.com/news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/religion/newdowus91405opn.pdf|title=Newdow v. Congress of the United States|author=|date=|website=findlaw.com|access-date=2018-02-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052152/http://fl1.findlaw.com/news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/religion/newdowus91405opn.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The Ninth Circuit rejected Newdow's challenge. In a decision published March 11, 2010, the court held that its earlier decision in ''Aronow'', which "held the national motto is of a "patriotic or ceremonial character," has no "theological or ritualistic impact," and does not constitute "governmental sponsorship of a religious exercise," foreclosed Newdow's argument.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2010/03/11/06-16344.pdf | title=Newdow v. Lefevre, No. 06-16344, at 4210 (9th Cir. Mar. 11, 2010) (citing ''Aronow'', 432 F.2d at 243–44).}}</ref> In an opinion concurring only in the judgment, even the extremely liberal Judge [[Stephen Reinhardt]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theweeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/001/414ilyss.asp | title=Matt Rees, ''The Judge the Supreme Court Loves to Overturn'', '''The Weekly Standard''', May 5, 1997; | access-date=2018-02-24 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516024714/http://www.theweeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/001/414ilyss.asp | archive-date=2010-05-16 | dead-url=yes | df= }} compare {{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-03-03/news/mn-42564_1_supreme-court | title=David G. Savage, ''Crusading Liberal Judge Keeps High Court Busy'', '''L.A. Times''', Mar. 3, 1996. | work=The Los Angeles Times | date=1996-03-03 }}</ref> agreed that ''Aronow'' was controlling precedent.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2010/03/11/06-16344.pdf | title=''Newdow'', at 4210–11 (Reinhardt, J., concurring).}}</ref>
''Newdow v. Congress'', 598 F.3d 638 (9th Cir. 2010) cert. denied 131 S. Ct. 1612 (U.S. 2011). AKA: The "In God We Trust Case" – A prominent atheist, Michael Newdow, filed a suit to declare the national motto – In God We Trust – unconstitutional and to have it removed from coins and currency.<ref name="egelko">Bob Egelko, 'In God We Trust' suit rejected by Supreme Court, ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', [http://www.sfgate.com/nation/article/In-God-We-Trust-suit-rejected-by-Supreme-Court-2471527.php] March 8, 2011</ref><ref name="ninth-circuit">[[Ninth Circuit]] [[Court of Appeals]], ''Newdow v. Congress'', [http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2010/03/11/06-16344.pdf] March 11, 2010</ref><ref name="oral-arguments">[[C-SPAN]] [[Video]] [[Library]], ''Establishment of Religion Clause Oral Arguments, Part 1'', [http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/ClauseO&showFullAbstract=1] December 7, 2007</ref> [[Pacific Justice Institute]] intervened as a defendant and defended against the suit.<ref name="egelko"/><ref name="ninth-circuit"/><ref name="oral-arguments"/> The case was dismissed by the trial court and the Ninth Circuit affirmed that decision.<ref name="egelko"/><ref name="ninth-circuit"/><ref name="oral-arguments"/>
In 2015, [[David F. Bauman]] dismissed a case against the [[Matawan-Aberdeen Regional School District]] brought by a student of the district and the [[American Humanist Association]] that argued that the phrase "under God" in the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] created a climate of discrimination because it promoted religion, making non-believers "second-class citizens".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/hearing-under-god-in-pledge-of-allegiance-does-not-violate-rights-of-atheist-students-nj-judge-rules-1.1332137|title=Hearing 'Under God' in Pledge of Allegiance does not violate rights of atheist students, NJ judge rules|author=Salvador Rizzo|work=NorthJersey.com|access-date=February 29, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maureensullivan/2015/02/07/judge-refuses-to-kick-god-out-of-public-schools/#11e06914435f|title=Judge Refuses To Kick God Out Of Public Schools|date=February 7, 2015|work=Forbes|access-date=February 29, 2016}}</ref> He noted; "As a matter of historical tradition, the words 'under God' can no more be expunged from the national consciousness than the words 'In God We Trust' from every coin in the land, than the words 'so help me God' from every presidential oath since 1789, or than the prayer that has opened every congressional session of legislative business since 1787."
Aside from constitutional objections, President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] took issue with using the motto on coinage as he considered using God's name on money to be [[sacrilege]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1907/11/14/archives/roosevelt-dropped-in-god-we-trust-president-says-such-a-motto-on.html|title=ROOSEVELT DROPPED 'IN GOD WE TRUST'; President Says Such a Motto on Coin Is Irreverence, Close to Sacrilege. NO LAW COMMANDS ITS USE He Trusts Congress Will Not Direct Him to Replace the Exalted Phrase That Invited Constant Levity|date=November 14, 1907|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=26 August 2010}}</ref>
In September 2014, a proposal to add displays of "In God We Trust" on public property in [[Ballwin, Missouri]] was defeated following a plea to a meeting of aldermen by a local atheist.<ref>https://www.riverfronttimes.com/newsblog/2014/09/24/ballwin-rejects-in-god-we-trust-sign-after-atheist-mothers-passionate-plea-video</ref><ref>http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/ballwin-rejects-in-god-we-trust-sign/article_ed39ceaf-242c-509d-aed6-1f9892489ae3.html</ref>
