Talk show hosts [[Stephen Colbert]] parodied Lochte's ''Today Show'' interview and compared his behavior to [[Donald Trump]],<ref>{{cite news|author=Melissa Locker |url=http://time.com/4462706/stephen-colberts-ryan-lochte-interview-trump/ |title=Stephen Colbert: Interview Ryan Lochte Spoof VIDEO |publisher=Time.com |date=2016-08-23 |accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Corinthios |first=Aurelie |url=http://www.people.com/article/ryan-lochte-stephen-colbert-parodies-swimmers-matt-lauer-interview |title=Ryan Lochte: Stephen Colbert Parodies Swimmer's Today Show Interview |publisher=People.com |date=2016-08-23 |accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref> while [[Jimmy Fallon]] parodied Lochte at the [[2016 MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Awards]] with attendee Michael Phelps' joy "noticeable from the start."<ref>{{cite news|author=Eliza Berman |url=http://time.com/4470235/vmas-2016-jimmy-fallon-ryan-lochte/ |title=2016 VMAs: Jimmy Fallon Spoofs Ryan Lochte in Blonde Wig |publisher=Time.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Edwards |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2016/08/29/jimmy-fallon-lies-away-as-he-channels-ryan-lochte-at-vma-awards.html |title=Jimmy Fallon brings out the lies as he channels Ryan Lochte at VMA awards | Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2016-08-26 |accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Weaver |first=Hilary |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/2016/08/michael-phelps-loved-jimmy-fallon-lochte-impersonation |title=Michael Phelps Loved Your Dad Jimmy Fallon’s Ryan Lochte Impersonation |publisher=Vanity Fair |date=2014-01-02 |accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref>
=== Aftermath in Brazil === In Brazil, the events "shocked and deeply angered Brazilians, who said it cast a false negative shadow on their city"<ref name="NBCOly" /> and was condemned for drawing additional attention to crime and violence in Rio de Janeiro.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/firestorm-over-us-swimmers-incident-continues-as-ryan-lochte-issues-apology/2016/08/19/ae5b55ac-6655-11e6-8b27-bb8ba39497a2_story.html |title= Firestorm over U.S. swimmers incident continues as Ryan Lochte issues apology |first1=Dave |last1=Sheinin |first2=Dom |last2=Phillips |first3=Joshua |last3=Partlow |date=August 19, 2016 |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |access-date= August 20, 2016 }}</ref> Some Brazilians drew parallels between the swimmers' actions and U.S. foreign policy.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
The [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]] gas station was incorporated into a commercial tour of Olympic sites, and reports an increase in paid customers and visitors taking selfies.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Nick Zaccardi|title=Gas station from Ryan Lochte, U.S. swimmers incident now a tourist attraction|url=http://olympics.nbcsports.com/2016/08/26/ryan-lochte-gas-station-rio-olympics-tourist-attraction/|website=nbcsports.com|publisher=NBC|accessdate=August 26, 2016|date=August 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/rio-2016/2016/08/20/ryan-lochte-accepts-responsibility-gas-station-robbery/89059926/ |title=Ryan Lochte accepts responsibility for gas station incident in NBC interview |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2016-08-21 |accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref>
=== Reactions by fellow athletes=== Fellow American swimmer [[Lilly King]] said, "It’s sad that people aren’t focusing on how well the U.S. Olympic team did. This might have been the best team we've ever had."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/sports/iu/IU-s-Lilly-King-has-more-barriers-to-break |title=IU’s Lilly King has more barriers to break - Indiana University |publisher=News-Sentinel.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref> Swimmer [[Maya DiRado]], who earned four medals said, "We wish that that hadn't taken attention away from our week of swimming because it was a phenomenal week for Team U.S.A. and U.S. swimming, and it was a phenomenal week on week two for those athletes on track and field." [[Conor Dwyer]] added, "It was tragic that the last week of the games that's all they're talking about and we don't want that to reflect poorly on U.S.A. swimming."<ref>{{cite web|last=Kimble |first=Lindsay |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,21026075,00.html |title=Swimmers Maya DiRado and Conor Dwyer Address Ryan Lochte Scandal |publisher=People.com |date=2016-08-23 |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref> [[Michael Phelps]] said, "It's always hard to see a friend and competitor go through a hard time like this. I know what it feels like and I've been through it before."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ward |first=Colin |url=http://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/michael-phelps-offers-sympathy-to-ryan-lochte-ive-been-through-it-before/ |title=Michael Phelps offers sympathy to Ryan Lochte: 'I've been through it before' |publisher=CBSSports.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref>
=== Marketability impact on involved swimmers === Marketers believed future professional and business opportunities for Gunnar Bentz, 20, and Jack Conger, 21, would be significantly reduced.<ref>{{cite web|last=Baker |first=Liana B. |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-rio-sponsors-swimmers-idUSKCN10U2EE |title=#LochteGate means lesser-known swimmers may miss their pay day |publisher=Reuters |date=2016-08-19 |accessdate=2016-08-27}}</ref>
[[MediaMiser]] reported Lochte's favorability rating changed from 90% positive on August 14–15 to 70% negative on August 17–18,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mediamiser.com/blog/2016/08/19/lochte-boys-timeline-olympic-controversy/ |title=Lochte and the Boys: Timeline of an Olympic controversy |publisher=MediaMiser |date=2016-08-19 |accessdate=2016-08-26}}</ref> with ''Forbes'' projecting a reduction of "at least $5-10 million in future lifetime income" due to damage to his personal brand.<ref>{{cite web|author=Patrick Rishe |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/prishe/2016/08/19/ryan-lochte-sinks-future-endorsement-potential-with-actions-worthy-of-an-olympic-gold-for-stupidity/#7a00a6af50d1 |title=Ryan Lochte Sinks Future Endorsement Potential With Actions Worthy Of An Olympic Gold For Stupidity |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-27}}</ref>
After Lochte's statements, [[Speedo]] and [[Ralph Lauren]] ended their endorsement deals with Lochte, with Speedo announcing that the company would donate $50,000 from Lochte's endorsement fee to [[Save the Children]] in Brazil.<ref name="SpeedoRL">{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/sports/2016/08/22/speedo-ends-sponsorship-ryan-lochte.html | title=Speedo USA, Ralph Lauren end Ryan Lochte endorsement deals | work=FoxNews | date=22 August 2016 | accessdate=22 August 2016}}</ref> The Brazilian newspaper [[O Globo]] reported that other sponsors of Ryan Lochte, the Airweave and [[Syneron Medical|Syneron Candela]] also terminated their contracts. According to a commentator and sports business analyst for [[ESPN]], [[Darren Rovell]], Lochte will lose US$1 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/ryan-lochte-perde-seus-quatro-patrocinadores-19971666 |language= Portuguese |title=Ryan Lochte perde seus quatro patrocinadores|publisher=[[O Globo]] |accessdate=August 22, 2016 |date=August 22, 2016}}</ref> However, Lochte signed new endorsement deals with Pine Bros Softish Throat Drops with the campaign slogan "Forgiving On Your Throat"<ref name="decline" /> and Robocopp, a crime prevention company, which manufactures a "sound grenade" designed to deter would-be robbers.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ben Rohrbach |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/a-crime-prevention-company-decided-ryan-lochte-was-a-worthy-sponsor-171856025.html |title=A crime prevention company decided Ryan Lochte was a worthy sponsor |publisher=Sports.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/sports/2016/08/31/ryan-lochte-gets-endorsement-from-company-that-can-get-out-bad-situation/ |title=Ryan Lochte cashing in on recent past, signs 2nd post-scandal endorsement | Fox News Latino |publisher=Latino.foxnews.com |date=2016-08-12 |accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref> Pine Bros CEO Rider McDowell told Yahoo Finance there was a 20% sales increase in the week following the signing.<ref>{{cite web|author=Daniel Roberts |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/ryan-lochtes-new-sponsor-its-not-like-hes-a-mass-murderer-195020353.html |title=Ryan Lochte’s new sponsor: It’s not like he’s 'a mass murderer' |publisher=Finance.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-12}}</ref>
He also joined ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 23)|Dancing with the Stars]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/08/can-ryan-lochte-redeem-himself-via-dancing-with-the-stars/497321/ |title=Can Ryan Lochte Redeem Himself on 'Dancing With the Stars'? |publisher=The Atlantic |date=2016-08-24 |accessdate=2016-08-30 |quote="Lochte may be looking to do what so many others have done before: rehab his reputation, one cha-cha at a time."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/ryan-lochte-set-join-dancing-stars-season-23-021440047.html |title=Ryan Lochte Set to Join ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Season 23 Cast (Report) |publisher=Yahoo.com |date=2016-08-25 |accessdate=2016-08-30 |quote="Of course, Lochte is far from the first scandal-plagued celebrity to go on “DWTS” to rehab their image. Paula Deen, Gary Busey, David Hasselhoff and newly-suspended soccer player Hope Solo all attempted to dance their way back into the public’s hearts."}}</ref> During the live installment of the season premiere, two men wearing anti-Lochte T-shirts rushed the stage while Lochte was receiving his scores. They were tackled by security guards, then arrested by the Los Angeles Police Department and charged with suspicion of criminal trespassing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2016/09/ryan-lochte-dancing-with-the-stars/499748/ |title=Ryan Lochte Ambushed on Dancing With the Stars Premiere |publisher=The Atlantic |date= |accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/4346982-155/lochte-feels-hurt-after-dancing-with |title=Lochte feels 'hurt' after 'Dancing with the Stars' incident | The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=Sltrib.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref>
Lochte stated his intent to participate in the Tokyo Olympics in 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://swimswam.com/lochte-confirms-plans-swim-tokyo-despite-rio-mistakes/ |title=Lochte Confirms Plans To Swim Through Tokyo Despite Rio Mistakes |publisher=Swimswam.com |date=2016-08-23 |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref> On August 26, Lochte announced that he will be making a celebrity appearance at a [[Wizard Entertainment|Wizard World]] Comic Con in [[Richmond, VA]] in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Swimmer Ryan Lochte to attend Comic Con in Richmond|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/aug/26/swimmer-ryan-lochte-to-attend-comic-con-in-richmon/|website=Washington Times|accessdate=30 August 2016|quote="Organizers for the Wizard World Comic Con say the 12-time Olympic medal winner will greet fans, sign autographs and pose for selfies with fans at the Greater Richmond Convention Center on Sept. 10."}}</ref>
=== Discipline of the athletes === On August 18, [[U.S. Olympic Committee]] CEO Scott Blackmun apologized for the incident<ref>{{cite web|author=Bill Chappell Twitter |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetorch/2016/08/18/490572609/we-apologize-to-rio-and-brazil-u-s-olympic-committee-chief-says |title='We Apologize' To Rio And Brazil, U.S. Olympic Committee Chief Says : The Torch |publisher=NPR |date=2016-08-18 |accessdate=2016-08-25}}</ref> On August 19, the International Olympic Committee created a disciplinary commission for the four swimmers, to investigate the matter and potentially sanction the athletes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2016/08/19/cnn-lochte-will-be-suspended-by-usa-swimming-us-olympic-commit/21455277/ |title=IOC sets up disciplinary commission for four US swimmers |publisher=AOL |date= |accessdate=2016-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ansari |first=Azadeh |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/08/20/sport/us-olympics-swimmers-reported-robbery-future/ |title=Ryan Lochte: 'I over-exaggerated' Olympics robbery story - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2016-08-22 |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref> On August 21, Blackmun stated that further action would occur involving the four, without commenting on specific disciplinary actions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/summer/swimming/story/_/id/17359335/scott-blackmun-us-olympic-committee-ceo-says-ryan-lochte-fellow-swimmers-disciplined |title=Scott Blackmun, U.S. Olympic Committee CEO, says Ryan Lochte, fellow swimmers will be disciplined |publisher=Espn.com |date=2016-08-21 |accessdate=2016-08-25}}</ref>
==== United States suspensions ==== On September 8, both the U.S. Olympic Committee and USA Swimming suspended Lochte for 10 months and Bentz, Conger and Feigen for four months.<ref name="punishment1">{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/swimming/story/_/id/17493633/ryan-lochte-suspended-10-months-united-states-olympic-committee-usa-swimming |title=Ryan Lochte suspended 10 months by United States Olympic Committee, USA Swimming |publisher=Espn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> Additionally, Lochte was required to complete 20 hours of community service and Bentz required to complete 10 hours.<ref name="punishment1" /> All were made ineligible for financial support during their suspensions, removed from the U.S. Olympic delegation to the White House, barred from U.S. Olympic training centers, and blocked from attending USA Swimming's year-end Golden Goggles celebration.<ref name="punishment1" />
Lochte's lawyer, Jeff Ostrow, declined to comment on the appropriateness of the sanctions, and reiterated that "Ryan did not commit a crime."<ref name="punishment1" /> Conger stated, "I do not agree in any way with these sanctions," and maintained that all he did wrong was to urinate publicly at the gas station.<ref name="punishment1" />
Blackmun's statement noted, "As we have said previously, the behavior of these athletes was not acceptable. It unfairly maligned our hosts and diverted attention away from the historic achievements of Team USA,"<ref name="punishment2">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-sn-swimmers-punished-20160908-snap-story.html |title=Ryan Lochte and three U.S. teammates receive penalties for lying about Rio robbery |publisher=LA Times |date= |accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> and "Each of the athletes has accepted responsibility for his actions and accepted the appropriate sanctions."<ref name="punishment1" /> Chuck Wielgus of USA Swimming stated, "Unfortunately, this storyline took attention away from the athletes who deserved it the most" and "These [swimmers] took accountability for their mistakes and are committed to represent themselves and our country with the great character and distinction we expect."<ref name="punishment2" /> <!-- presumptive sections for ===International Olympic Committee sanctions=== -->
== Commentary==
=== Gender equality === {{Quote box|width=20%|align=right|quote="U.S. Soccer is obviously not in charge of Lochte's punishment. But someone is. And if Solo can get kicked off a team and potentially never play for the U.S. again, then Lochte should get more than a stern talking to, some lost endorsements, and a new reality TV show deal."|author=Sarah Rense|source=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire.com]]<ref name="esq" />}} Several opinion writers criticised the contrasting consequences faced by Lochte to both women's goalkeeper [[Hope Solo]], who was suspended for six months after making unsportsmanlike post-game comments,<ref name="esq">{{cite web|last=Rense |first=Sarah |url=http://www.esquire.com/lifestyle/sex/news/a48009/hope-solo-fired-us-soccer/ |title=Why Is Hope Solo's Punishment Far Worse Than Ryan Lochte's? |publisher=Esquire.com |date=2016-08-25 |accessdate=2016-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hamblin |first=Abby |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/aug/25/hope-solos-punishment-for-olympics-comment/ |title=Hope Solo's punishment: too harsh, sexist or spot on? |publisher=SanDiegoUnionTribune.com |date=2016-08-25 |accessdate=2016-08-30 |quote="However, many rose to defend her, saying the suspension was way too harsh, especially in comparison to the few consequences Ryan Lochte faced after his Olympic debacle."}}</ref> and American gymnast [[Gabby Douglas]].<ref name="NPR" /><ref name="huffpo" /> An ''[[Associated Press]]'' columnist stated, "A triumphant Olympics for the U.S. team—especially all those golden female athletes—has come with some nasty aftershocks, raising more potential questions about gender inequality."<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Newberry |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2016/08/26/column-solo-lochte-and-a-look-at-gender-equality-after-rio/89434654/ |title=Column: Solo, Lochte and a look at gender equality after Rio |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2016-08-26 |accessdate=2016-08-30 }}</ref> ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' criticized the general treatment of male athletes including past Olympians,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mary Elizabeth Williams |url=http://www.salon.com/2016/08/19/the-ballad-of-swim-shady-ryan-lochtes-rio-fiasco-is-more-proof-that-male-athletes-are-a-protected-class/ |title=The ballad of "Swim Shady": Ryan Lochte’s Rio fiasco is more proof that male athletes are a protected class |publisher=Salon.com |date=2016-08-19 |accessdate=2016-08-30 |quote=It must be a heady thing to have all the privileges of a male athlete. You can pretty much do anything before you’re held even remotely accountable — and then when you do have to face any consequences, you’ll get a nice chorus of despair about your lost opportunities. In what other realm could the misdeeds of a 32-year-old man be gently passed off as the antics of "kids?"}}</ref> while ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' noted the impact in which "NBC wants to both showcase women athletes and attract female viewers."<ref>{{cite web|author=Sonia Saraiya |url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/columns/rio-2016-olympics-stars-ryan-lochte-simone-biles-gabby-douglas-1201840600/ |title=Olympics 2016: Women Like Biles, Not Lochte, Are the Stars at Rio |publisher=Variety |date=2016-08-19 |accessdate=2016-08-30|quote=It’s moments like this that make the Lochte story stand out in such amusing contrast; the seriousness and sportsmanship of the women, in comparison to what might be egregious idiocy, if not an outright crime, on the part of four male swimmers.}}</ref>
=== White privilege === [[File:Gabby Douglas - Rio 2016 02.jpg|thumb|200 px|Gymnast [[Gabby Douglas]] in Rio]] Several opinion pieces drew links to [[white privilege]],<ref name="huffpo">{{cite web|author=Emma Gray Executive Women's Editor, The Huffington Post |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ryan-lochte-gabby-douglas-and-white-male-privilege-in-action_us_57b5e76de4b034dc73262f93 |title=White Male Privilege Is Why We Laugh At Lochte And Vilify Douglas |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-26 |quote="Gymnast Gabby Douglas “disrespected” her entire country by not putting her hand on her heart and smiling enough during the Olympics. Swimmer Ryan Lochte is a “kid” who deserves “a break” for allegedly destroying property and lying about a traumatic robbery. If you were wondering what white, male privilege looks like, this is it."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Dani Bostick|title=USA SWIMMING'S SILENCE ON RYAN LOCHTE IS WRONG|url=http://fansided.com/2016/08/23/usa-swimmings-silence-ryan-locthe-irresponsible/|website=fansided.com|publisher=FanSided|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 23, 2016 |quote="Intentionally or not, the incident also further cleaves open the dialogue on white privilege. After all, Cam Newton, a black NFL quarterback, was vilified for sulking after his team’s loss to the Denver Broncos. Meanwhile, Lochte-the-vandal apparently gets a free pass — at the upper echelons of his sport, no less — as a well-meaning, fun-loving kid. If you’re white, vandalizing a gas station in a foreign country and then lying about it is akin to wearing grillz to a press conference (which Lochte has also done)."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=A. B. Wilkinson|title=Bleaching The 2016 Olympics: Lochte, Anthony Ervin, And Race In Rio|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/a-b-wilkinson/bleaching-the-2016-olympics_b_11658094.html|website=huffingtonpost.com|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 23, 2016 |quote="While Ryan Lochte is an easy target, his actions are emblematic of a larger colonial mindset that has a long history of 'white privilege' and upholding systems that support Anglo-conformity and the blanquemiento (whitening) of American society."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Dear Fellow White People|title=Dear Fellow White People|url=http://theundefeated.com/features/dear-fellow-white-people/|website=TheUndefeated.com|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 23, 2016 |quote="The 2016 Rio de Janeiro Games have brought to my attention that some of us still don’t quite grasp what white privilege is. Or, even if we do feel like we get the concept, it’s still difficult to fully comprehend the way that privilege has set up a double standard that is so infuriating — and disheartening — to people of color."}}</ref><ref name="vibe">{{cite web|author=Vibe |url=http://www.vibe.com/2016/08/lochtegate-shows-white-privilege-at-rio-olympics/ |title=White Privilege Runs Deep With #LochteGate |publisher=Vibe.com |date=2016-08-18 |accessdate=2016-08-27 |quote="The incident has been dubbed #LochteGate, or in some circles, #LochteMess. Either way, the very tangled story has revealed what we already know about white privilege and the lingering problems the nation faces among other countries."}}</ref> while others refuted the charge.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Clay Travis|title=ESPN Argues Ryan Lochte Represents White Privilege, Fails Miserably|url=http://www.outkickthecoverage.com/espn-argues-ryan-lochte-is-white-privilege-fails-miserably-082416|website=outkickthecoverage.com |publisher=Fox Sports|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 24, 2016 |quote="Yesterday ESPN published a perfect example of this newfound editorial direction, an article holding up Ryan Lochte as the perfect example of white privilege. The article was flawed in every way, which I'm going to demonstrate by systematically disemboweling every argument made in the story."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cauterucci |first=Christina |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/fivering_circus/2016/08/should_we_feel_bad_for_ryan_lochte.html |title=Should we feel bad for Ryan Lochte? |publisher=Slate.com |date=2016-08-19 |accessdate=2016-08-26 |quote="But for the last week, Lochte has been treated as either the village idiot or a symbol of white privilege who explains everything that is wrong with our society. His crimes don’t warrant either (and the first is quite frankly a bit offensive)."}}</ref> ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'' stated, "Lochte's tale of being robbed by seemingly corrupt cops was not only in line with what many already believed about nations full of people of color, but it also tainted the spirit of the entire games."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebony.com/news-views/ryan-lochte-robbery#ixzz4Hn75bWGK |title=The Ryan Lochte "Robbery" Story is the Epitome of White Privilege |publisher=EBONY |date=2016-08-18 |accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref> Leah Donella, a news assistant at [[NPR]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Leah Donnella|url=https://www.npr.org/people/477473044/leah-donnella|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=14 November 2016}}</ref> observed, "Lochte's own background — he's half Cuban, another country with an extremely complex racial history — further complicates that narrative."<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|author1=Leah Donnella |title=Roundup: Smart Thoughts On Ryan Lochte And White Privilege|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2016/08/19/490629815/roundup-smart-thoughts-on-ryan-lochte-and-white-privilege|website=NPR.com|publisher=NPR|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 19, 2016}}</ref>
Some negatively contrasted the treatment of the scandal involving white swimmers against the reaction received by African-American gymnast [[Gabby Douglas#2016 Summer Olympic Games|Gabby Douglas]] for not placing her hand over her heart during the national anthem.<ref name="prdaily1"/><ref name="NPR" /><ref name="huffpo" /><ref name="vibe" />
=== Political corruption === <!--This stub is not a true orphan and could be fleshed out with the overlapping piece currently in the social media section--> Other commentary compared the incident to [[political corruption]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oznian|first1=Mike|title=Ryan Lochte Episode Is About Brazil Trying To Embarrass The U.S. And Shakedown Its Swimmers|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2016/08/19/ryan-lochte-episode-is-about-brazil-trying-to-embarrass-the-u-s-and-shakedown-its-swimmers/#6c481c6c7b61|website=Forbes|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 19, 2016}}</ref> calling the exchange of money to drop criminal charges a "shakedown."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schuppe|first1=Jon|title=Robbery, Shakedown or Misunderstanding? How the Ryan Lochte Stickup Story Unfolded|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2016-rio-summer-olympics/robbery-or-not-how-ryan-lochte-stickup-story-unfolded-n633561|website=NBCNews|accessdate=August 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Swanberg|first1=Conor|title=Brazil Demanded $11,000 ‘Shakedown’ From Team USA Swimmer Involved in Lochte Scandal|url=http://ijr.com/2016/08/678602-brazil-demanded-11000-shakedown-from-team-usa-swimmer-involved-in-lochte-scandal/|accessdate=August 25, 2016|agency=Independent Journal|date=August 23, 2016}}</ref>

He was also the main political leader of the [[Alliance of Builders of Islamic Iran]], a coalition of conservative political groups in the country. An engineer and teacher from a poor background,[http://www.president.ir/eng/ahmadinejad/bio/ Biography of H.E. Dr. Ahmadi Nejad, Honourable President of Islamic Republic of Iran]. Retrieved 27 January 2008. {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080103/http://www.president.ir/eng/ahmadinejad/bio/ |date=3 January 2008 }} ideologically shaped by thinkers such as [[Navvab Safavi]], [[Jalal Al-e-Ahmad]] and [[Ahmad Fardid]],Avideh Mayville, "The Religious Ideology of Reform in Iran" in [[J. Harold Ellens]] (ed.), ''Winning Revolutions: The Psychosocial Dynamics of Revolts for Freedom, Fairness, and Rights [3 volumes]'', ABC-CLIO (2013), p. 311 Ahmadinejad joined the [[Office for Strengthening Unity]]{{cite web|title=Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|publisher=Iran Chamber Society | url = http://www.iranchamber.com/history/mahmadinejad/mahmoud_ahmadinejad.php|accessdate=28 July 2009}} after the [[Iranian Revolution]]. Appointed a provincial governor, he was removed after the election of President [[Mohammad Khatami]] and returned to teaching.{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Jon |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/04/13/090413fa_fact_anderson|title=Can Iran Change? High stakes in Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's reelection campaign|work=New Yorker|date=7 January 2009|accessdate=18 June 2011}} Tehran's council elected him mayor in 2003.{{cite web| first= John| last= Pike|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/iran/ahmadinejad.htm |title=President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|publisher=Global Security|accessdate=18 June 2011}} He took a religious hard line, reversing reforms of previous moderate mayors.{{cite web|url=http://entekhab.ir/display/?ID=2648 |title="Ahamd Bozorgian (MP): 'The Separation of men and women's elevators is an advantageous policy. It would help to grow.'" |accessdate=2005-06-20 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060114020232/http://entekhab.ir/display/?ID=2648 |archivedate=14 January 2006 |df= }} Entekhab News. Retrieved 31 August 2006. His 2005 presidential campaign, supported by the [[Alliance of Builders of Islamic Iran]], garnered 62% of the [[runoff election]] votes, and he became President on 3 August 2005.{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad Sworn in as Iran's New President|date=6 August 2005|work=Voice Of America|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2005-08/2005-08-06-voa8.cfm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129182648/http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2005-08/2005-08-06-voa8.cfm|archivedate=2009-01-29|accessdate=23 December 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4740441.stm|title=Iran hardliner becomes president|accessdate=6 December 2006|date=3 August 2005|work=BBC}} During his presidency, Ahmadinejad was a controversial figure within [[Iran]], as well as internationally. He has been criticized domestically for his economic policiesHafezi, Parisa. "[https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/08/13/us-iran-economy-cleric-idUSHAF34205520080813 Influential Iran cleric slams Ahmadinejad on economy]" Reuters, 13 August 2008 and disregard for [[human rights]].Memarian, Omid. "[http://www.ipsnews.net/2010/09/activists-warn-of-rights-crisis-ahead-of-ahmadinejad-visit/ Activists Warn of Rights Crisis Ahead of Ahmadinejad Visit]". Inter Press Service, 17 September 2010 Internationally, he is criticized for his hostility towards some countries, most notably [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Israel]], the [[United Kingdom]], and the [[United States of America|United States]] and other Western and Arab nations. In 2007, Ahmadinejad introduced a [[2007 Gas Rationing Plan in Iran|gas rationing plan]] to reduce the country's fuel consumption, and cut the interest rates that private and public banking facilities could charge.{{cite news|first=Robert|last=Tait |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/may/25/iran.internationalnews|title=Iran interest rate cut sparks panic selling |work=The Guardian |date=25 May 2007|accessdate=18 June 2011|location=Tehran}}[http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/story/2007/07/070710_ka-mpo.shtmlسازمان مدیریت و" برنامه ریزی منحل ش"], BBC Persian. Retrieved 29 July 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817164633/http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/story/2007/07/070710_ka-mpo.shtml |date=17 August 2007 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=175959|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912183345/http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=175959|archivedate=2008-09-12|title=Assembly of Experts to study economic reform plan: Rafsanjani|accessdate=23 August 2008|date=23 August 2008|language=Persian|work=Tehran Times}} He supports [[Iran nuclear program|Iran's nuclear program]]. His [[Iran presidential election, 2009|election to a second term in 2009]] was widely disputed{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8134904.stm|title=Iran clerics defy election ruling|publisher=BBC News|date=5 July 2009|accessdate=18 June 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/07/090704_op_brief_majma_qom.shtml|title=Is this government legitimate?|publisher=BBC|date=7 September 2009|accessdate=18 June 2011}} and caused widespread [[2009–2010 Iranian election protests|protests domestically]] and drew significant international criticism.{{cite web|last=Landry|first=Carole |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jSWPwBGmOByDmvG6OPfqesxJ2O7Q|title=G8 calls on Iran to halt election violence|publisher=Google|date=25 June 2009|accessdate=18 June 2011}} During his second term, Ahmadinejad came under fire not only from reformers but also traditionalists in parliament and the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guard]], and even from Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]], over accusations of corruption, Ahmadinejad's dismissal of Intelligence minister [[Gholam-Hossein Mohseni-Eje'i]], and his support for his controversial close adviser [[Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei]]. On 14 March 2012, Ahmadinejad became the first president of the Islamic Republic of Iran to be summoned by the [[Islamic Consultative Assembly]] (parliament) to answer questions regarding his presidency.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2012/mar/14/iran-ahmadinejad-appears-parliament |title=Iran's president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad summoned to parliament|work=The Guardian |date=14 March 2012| access-date=18 December 2012}}[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18328882 Ahmadinejad critic Larijani re-elected Iran speaker]. BBC (5 June 2012). Retrieved on 18 December 2012. Limited to two terms under the current [[Iranian constitution]], Ahmadinejad supported Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei's campaign for president.{{cite news|last=Erdbrink |first=Thomas|title=Power Struggle Is Gripping Iran Ahead of June Election |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/04/world/middleeast/ahmadinejad-of-iran-reshapes-image-ahead-of-june-vote.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|accessdate=4 April 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=3 April 2013}} On 15 June 2013, [[Hassan Rouhani]] was [[Iranian presidential election, 2013|elected]] as Ahmadinejad's successor and assumed office on 3 August 2013. On 12 April 2017, Ahmadinejad announced that he intended to run for a third term in the [[Iranian presidential election, 2017|2017 Iranian presidential election]], against the objections of Supreme Leader [[Ayatollah Khamenei]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/04/12/world/middleeast/ap-ml-iran-elections.html?_r=0 |title=Hard-Line Ex-Leader Ahmadinejad Stuns Iran With Election Bid|work=The New York Times|date=12 April 2017}} His nomination was rejected by the [[Guardian Council]].{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/mahmoud-ahmadinejad-disqualified-iran-elections-170420190716061.html|title=Mahmoud Ahmadinejad 'disqualified' from Iran elections|date=20 April 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/04/20/iranian-president-hassan-rouhani-and-hardline-rival-ebrahim-raisi-cleared-to|title=Iran's Ahmadinejad disqualified from running for the president|date=20 April 2017}} During the [[2017–18 Iranian protests]] Ahmedinejad criticized the current government of Iran. ==Early life== Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was born on 28 October 1956 near [[Garmsar]], in the village of [[Aradan, Iran|Aradan]], in [[Semnan province]]. His mother, Khanom, was a [[Sayyid]]a, an [[honorific]] title given to those believed to be direct bloodline descendants of the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]]. His father, Ahmad, was a grocer and barber, and was a religious [[Shia Islam|Shia]] who taught the [[Quran]].{{cite book|last=Melman|first=Yossi|first2=Meir |last2=Javedanfar|title=The Nuclear Sphinx of Tehran: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and the State of Iran|publisher=Basic Books|year=2007|pages=1–3|isbn=9780786718870}} When Mahmoud was one year old, his family moved to [[Tehran]]. Mahmoud's father changed their [[family name]] from "Saborjhian"{{cite news|first=Robert |last=Tait|title=A humble beginning helped to form Iran's new hard man|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 July 2005|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jul/02/iran.roberttait|accessdate=27 July 2009 |location=Tehran}} or "Sabaghian"{{efn|Kasra Naji says that the name was 'Sabaghian,' which means 'dye-masters' in [[Persian language|Persian]].{{cite book|first=Kasra|last=Naji|title=Ahmadinejad: The Secret History of Iran's Radical Leader|publisher=University of California Press |year=2008|isbn=9781845116361|page=4}}}} to Ahmadinejad in 1960 to avoid discrimination when the family moved to the city. ''Sabor'' is Persian for thread painter,{{efn|In 2009, some media reports claimed that Sabourjian is a common Iranian Jewish name, and that ''Sabor'' is the name for the Jewish [[tallit]] (prayer shawl) in Persia.{{cite news|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=3 October 2009|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/6256173/Mahmoud-Ahmadinejad-revealed-to-have-Jewish-past.html |title=Mahmoud Ahmadinejad revealed to have Jewish past}} [[Meir Javedanfar]], a blogger at ''The Guardian'', disputed this claim, citing experts.{{cite news|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 October 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/oct/05/mahmoud-ahmadinejad-jewish-family |title=Ahmadinejad has no Jewish roots|access-date=10 January 2017}}}} a once common occupation within the Semnan carpet industry. Ahmadinejad's uncle and his brother [[Davoud Ahmadinejad]] have confirmed that the previous surname was "Sabbaghian" ({{lang-fa|صباغیان}}). Ahmadinejad is a composite name: Ahmadi Nejad. Ahmad is to a name applied for Muhammad, the prophet of Islam, and namely virtuous. The suffix ''Nejad'' in Persian means race, therefore the term Ahmadi Nejad means "the race of Muhammad". According to the interviews with the relatives of Ahmadi Nejad, his father who works in small shop, sold his house in Tehran and bought a smaller one, giving the leftover to charity and poor people.{{cite book|first1=Anoushiravan|last1=Enteshami |first2=Mahjoob|last2=Zweiri |title=Iran and the rise of Neoconservatives, the politics of Tehran's silent Revolution|year=2007 |page=53|publisher=I. B. Tauris}} In 1976, Ahmadinejad took Iran's national university entrance examination. According to his autobiography, he was ranked 132nd out of 400,000 participants that year,{{cite news|title=Iran's president launches weblog |publisher=BBC|date=14 August 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4790005.stm|accessdate=28 July 2009}} and soon enrolled in the [[Iran University of Science and Technology]] (IUST), located at Tehran, as an undergraduate student of civil engineering. He would later earn his doctorate in 1997 in transportation engineering and planning from Iran University of Science and Technology as well, when he was the mayor of Ardabil Province, located at the north-west of the country. ==Administrative and academic careers== Some details of Ahmadinejad's life during the 1980s are not publicly known, but it is known that he held a number of administrative posts in the province of [[West Azerbaijan]], [[Iran]]. Many reports say that after [[Saddam Hussein]] ordered the invasion of Iran, Ahmadinejad joined the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]] and served in their intelligence and security apparatus, but his advisor Mojtaba Samareh Hashemi says, "He has never been a member or an official member of the Revolutionary Guards", having been a [[Basiji]]-like volunteer instead.{{cite web| first=Najmeh |last=Bozorgmehr|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3c04bcbc-2d9e-11dd-b92a-000077b07658,dwp_uuid=be75219e-940a-11da-82ea-0000779e2340.html?nclick_check=1|title=Interview transcript: Mojtaba Samareh-Hashemi|accessdate=28 July 2009|date=30 May 2008|work=[[Financial Times]]}} Ahmadinejad was accepted to a [[Master of Science]] program at his alma mater in 1986. He joined the faculty there as a lecturer in 1989,{{cite web|first=Hussein D.|last=Hassan|title=Profile and Statements of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=16 January 2007|url=http://brownback.senate.gov/public/legissues/foreignpol_crsreportiranprofilestateofpres.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106163238/http://brownback.senate.gov/public/legissues/foreignpol_crsreportiranprofilestateofpres.pdf|archivedate=6 January 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2009}} and in 1997 received his [[doctorate]] in civil engineering and traffic transportation planning. ==Early political career== After the [[Islamic Revolution]], Ahmadinejad became a member of the [[Office for Strengthening Unity]], an organization developed to prevent students from sympathizing or allying with the budding [[People's Mujahedin of Iran|Mojahedin-e Khalq]]. He first took political office as unelected governor to both [[Maku, Iran|Maku]] and [[Khoy]] in [[West Azarbaijan Province]] during the 1980s. He eventually became an advisor to the governor general of [[Kurdistan province (Iran)|Kurdistan Province]] for two years. During his doctoral studies at Tehran, he was appointed governor general of newly formed [[Ardabil Province]] from 1993 until [[Mohammad Khatami]] removed him in 1997, whereupon he returned to teaching. ==Mayor of Tehran== The 2003 mayoral race in Tehran elected [[conservative]] candidates from the [[Alliance of Builders of Islamic Iran]] to the [[City Council of Tehran]]. The Council appointed Ahmadinejad [[Mayor of Tehran|mayor]]. As mayor, he reversed changes made by previous [[moderate]] and [[reformism|reformist]] mayors. He put religious emphasis on the activities of cultural centres they had founded, publicised the separation of [[elevator]]s for men and women in the municipality offices, and suggested that people killed in the [[Iran–Iraq War]] be buried in major [[city square]]s of Tehran. He also worked to improve the traffic system and put an emphasis on [[Charity (virtue)|charity]], such as distributing free soup to the poor. After his election to the presidency, Ahmadinejad's resignation as the Mayor of Tehran was accepted on 28 June 2005. After two years as mayor, Ahmadinejad was one of 65 finalists for [[World Mayor]] in 2005, selected from 550 nominees, only nine of them from Asia. He was among three strong candidates for the top-ten list, but his resignation made him ineligible.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldmayor.com/results05/worldmayor_finalists05.html|title=The 2005 World Mayor finalists|publisher=World Mayor|accessdate=18 June 2011}} ==Presidency== {{further|Government of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad (2005–2013)}} ===2005 Campaign=== [[File:Mahmoud Ahmadinejad - June 21, 2005.png|thumb|155px|Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in a press conference, 21 June 2005]] Ahmadinejad was not widely known when he entered the presidential election campaign as he had never run for office before, (he had been mayor of Tehran for only two years and had been appointed, not elected),{{cite book|last=Wright|first=Robin|title=Dreams and Shadows: The Future of the Middle East|publisher=Penguin Press|year=2008 |isbn=9781101202760}}{{rp|315}} although he had already made his mark in Tehran for rolling back earlier reforms. He was/is a member of the [[Islamic Society of Engineers|Central Council of the Islamic Society of Engineers]], but his key political support is inside the [[Alliance of Builders of Islamic Iran]] (''Abadgaran'' or ''Developers'').Aneja, Atul (2006). He was also known as tir khalas zan before becoming president.{{cite web|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2326/stories/20070112001105500.htm |title="New Dynamics." |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016202546/http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2326/stories/20070112001105500.htm |archivedate=16 October 2007 |df=}} Frontline. Retrieved 28 July 2007. He was also helped by support from supreme leader [[Ali Khamenei]], who some described Ahmadinejad as a "protege" of.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/19/ahmadinejad-iran-power-struggle |title=Ahmadinejad's enemies scent blood in Iran power struggle|first1=Saeed Kamali|last1=Dehghan |first2=Julian|last2=Borger|work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2011}} Ahmadinejad generally sent mixed signals about his plans for his presidency, perhaps to attract both [[religious conservative]]s and the lower economic classes.{{cite news|first=Karl |last=Vick|title=Hard-Line Figure In Iran Runoff|work=The Washington Post|date=19 June 2005|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/18/AR2005061801226_pf.html |accessdate=28 July 2009}} His campaign slogan was: "It's possible and we can do it". In the campaign, he took a populist approach. He emphasized his own modest life, and compared himself with [[Mohammad Ali Rajai]], Iran's second president. Ahmadinejad said he planned to create an "exemplary government for the people of the world" in Iran. He was a "[[principlist]]", acting politically based on Islamic and revolutionary principles. One of his goals was "putting the petroleum income on people's tables", meaning Iran's oil profits would be distributed among the poor.{{cite news |first= S. |last= Moubayed|title=Iran and the art of crisis management|newspaper=Asia Times |date=19 January 2006|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/HA19Ak03.html|accessdate=28 July 2009}} Ahmadinejad was the only presidential candidate who spoke out against future relations with the United States. He told [[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]] the [[United Nations]] was "one-sided, stacked against the world of Islam."Brea, Jennifer. [http://worldnews.about.com/od/iran/p/ahmadinejad.htm "Profile: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, President of Iran."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707075150/http://worldnews.about.com/od/iran/p/ahmadinejad.htm |date=7 July 2011 }}. Retrieved 31 August 2006. He opposed the [[UN Security Council Veto Power|veto power]] of the [[UN Security Council]]'s five permanent members: "It is not just for a few states to sit and veto global approvals. Should such a privilege continue to exist, the Muslim world with a population of nearly 1.5 billion should be extended the same privilege." He defended [[Iran's nuclear program]] and accused "a few arrogant powers" of trying to limit Iran's industrial and technological development in this and other fields. In his second-round campaign, he said, "We didn't participate in the revolution for turn-by-turn government....This revolution tries to reach a world-wide government." He spoke of an extended program using trade to improve foreign relations, and called for greater ties with Iran's neighbours and ending [[Visa (document)|visa]] requirements between states in the region, saying that "people should visit anywhere they wish freely. People should have freedom in their [[pilgrimage]]s and tours."{{cite web|first=Babnet |last=Tunisia |title=More on Mahmoud Ahmadinejad |work=Persian Mirror |year=2005 |url=http://persianmirror.com/community/2005/opinion/MahmoudAhmadinejad.cfm |accessdate=2 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626204105/http://persianmirror.com/community/2005/opinion/MahmoudAhmadinejad.cfm |archivedate=26 June 2009 |df= }} Ahmadinejad described [[Ayatollah]] [[Mohammad Taghi Mesbah Yazdi]], a senior cleric from [[Qom]], as his ideological and spiritual mentor. Mesbah founded the [[Haghani Circle|Haghani]] School of thought in Iran. He and his team strongly supported Ahmadinejad's 2005 presidential campaign.{{cite web|first=Nazenin|last=Ansari|title=Divide and empower|work=Prospect Magazine|date=25 June 2006|url=http://www.prospect-magazine.co.uk/article_details.php?id=7487 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207110527/http://www.prospect-magazine.co.uk/article_details.php?id=7487 |archivedate=2008-12-07|accessdate=2 August 2009}} ===2005 Presidential election=== {{Main|Iranian presidential election, 2005}} Ahmadinejad won 62% of the vote in the [[runoff election|run-off poll]] against [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]. [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah Khamenei]] authorized his presidency on 3 August 2005. Ahmedinejad kissed Khamenei's hand during the ceremony to show his loyalty.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/08/world/africa/08iht-khamenei.2748833.html|title=Behind Ahmadinejad, a Powerful Cleric| accessdate=11 January 2017 |date=8 September 2006|work=The New York Times|first=Michael|last=Slackman}}{{cite web|url=http://tofoiran.packdeal.com/clips/DrIman/20060906-DrIman-CNN-225.asx |title=Clip DrIman CNN – at Tofoiran |date=6 September 2006 |accessdate=18 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715032350/http://tofoiran.packdeal.com/clips/DrIman/20060906-DrIman-CNN-225.asx |archivedate=15 July 2011 |df= }} Shortly after Ahmadinejad was elected president, some [[western media outlets]] published claims that he was among the students who [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and the 1979 hostage crisis|stormed the US embassy in Tehran]], sparking the [[Iran hostage crisis]]. This claim has been denied by the Iranian government, the Iranian opposition, as well as a CIA investigation on the matter.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} ===2005 Cabinet appointments=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:10px; float:right;" |- !
