|url=http://www.servat.unibe.ch/icl/ir00000_.html#A133_|publisher=International Constitutional Law|year=1992|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Ahmadinejad presented a short-list at a private meeting on 5 August, and his final list on 14 August. The Majlis rejected all of his cabinet candidates for the oil portfolio and objected to the appointment of his allies in senior government office. The Majlis approved a cabinet on 24 August.{{cite web|url=http://president.ir/ahmadinejad/cronicnews/1384/06/02/index-f.htm |title="Ahmadinejad's cabinet declared." |accessdate=2009-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060111212405/http://president.ir/ahmadinejad/cronicnews/1384/06/02/index-f.htm |archivedate=11 January 2006 |df= }} Presidency of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Retrieved 18 October 2006. The ministers promised to meet frequently outside Tehran and held their first meeting on 25 August in [[Mashhad]], with four empty seats for the unapproved nominees.{{cite news|title=Depleted Iran cabinet meets after rejection of four by parliament |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2005/August/middleeast_August739.xml§ion=middleeast&col= |work=Khaleej Times Online |date=26 August 2005 |accessdate=2 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608214526/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data%2Fmiddleeast%2F2005%2FAugust%2Fmiddleeast_August739.xml§ion=middleeast&col= |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df= }} ===2006 Councils and Assembly of Experts election=== {{Main|Iranian councils election, 2006|Iranian Assembly of Experts election, 2006}} Ahmadinejad's team lost the 2006 city council elections. In the first nationwide election since Ahmadinejad became President, his allies failed to dominate election returns for the [[Assembly of Experts]] and local councils. Results, with a turnout of about 60%, suggested a voter shift toward more moderate policies. According to an editorial in the Kargozaran independent [[daily newspaper]], "The results show that voters have learned from the past and concluded that we need to support.. moderate figures." An Iranian political analyst said that "this is a blow for Ahmadinejad and [[Mohammad Taqi Mesbah-Yazdi|Mesbah Yazdi's]] list."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/17/AR2006121700772.html|title=Results in Iranian Vote Seen as Setback for Ahmadinejad|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=18 December 2006|accessdate=18 June 2011|first=Edmund|last=Blair}} ===2009 Presidential election=== {{Main|Iranian presidential election, 2009}} On 23 August 2008, Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei announced that he "sees Ahmadinejad as president in the next five years," a comment interpreted as indicating support for Ahmadinejad's reelection.{{cite web|url=https://www.memri.org/reports/renewed-power-struggle-iran-presidential-elections-approach-part-i-%e2%80%93-ahmadinejads| title=Renewed Power Struggle in Iran as the Presidential Elections Approach: Part I – Ahmadinejad's Revolutionary-Messianic Faction vs. Rafsanjani–Reformist Alliance|first1=Y. |last1=Mansharof|first2=A. |last2=Savyon|publisher=The Middle East Media Research Institute |date=26 December 2008|access-date=11 January 2017}} 39,165,191 ballots were cast in the election on 12 June 2009, according to Iran's election headquarters. Ahmadinejad won 24,527,516 votes, (62.63%). In second place, [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]], won 13,216,411 (33.75%) of the votes.{{cite news |publisher=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8098305.stm|date=13 June 2009|accessdate=13 June 2009|title=Ahmadinejad 'leads in Iran election'}} ===2009 Iranian Presidential election protests=== {{Main|2009 Iranian election protests}} The election results remained in dispute with both Mousavi and Ahmadinejad and their respective supporters who believe that [[electoral fraud]] occurred during the election. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei formally endorsed Ahmadinejad as President on 3 August 2009, and Ahmadinejad was sworn in for a second term on 5 August 2009. Iran's Constitution stipulates [[term limits]] of two terms for the office of President.{{cite web |url=http://www.photius.com/countries/iran/government/iran_government_the_presidency.html|title=Iran The Presidency |website=Photius.com |accessdate=18 June 2011}} Several Iranian political figures appeared to avoid the ceremony. Former presidents [[Mohammad Khatami]], and [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]], who is currently head of the [[Expediency Discernment Council]], along with opposition leader Mir Hossein Mousavi, did not attend the ceremony.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8180811.stm| title=Iran poll critics shun ceremony|accessdate=5 August 2009|date=3 August 2009|publisher=BBC}} Opposition groups asked protesters on reformist websites and blogs to launch new street demonstrations on the day of the inauguration ceremony.{{Cite news|title=Iran's opposition calls for inauguration protests|url=http://www.journal-news.net/page/content.detail/id/523324/Iran-s-opposition-calls-for-inauguration-protests.html| publisher=Google News|agency=Associated Press|date=4 August 2009|accessdate=5 August 2009}} On inauguration day, hundreds of riot police met opposition protesters outside parliament. After taking the oath of office, which was broadcast live on [[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting|Iranian state television]], Ahmadinejad said that he would "protect the official faith, the system of the Islamic revolution and the constitution." France, Germany, the United Kingdom and the United States announced that they would not send the usual letters of congratulation.{{Cite news|date=5 August 2009|accessdate=5 August 2009|title=Defiant Iran president takes oath|publisher=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8184240.stm}} ===2009 Cabinet appointments=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:10px; float:right;" |- ! Ministry ! Minister |- | [[Agriculture in Iran|Agriculture]] || [[Sadeq Khalilian]] |- | [[Ministry of Commerce (Iran)|Commerce]] || [[Mehdi Ghazanfari]] |- | [[Communications in Iran|Communication and Information Technology]] || [[Reza Taghipour]] |- | [[Ministry of Cooperatives (Iran)|Cooperatives]] || [[Mohammad Abbasi]] |- | [[Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance|Culture and Islamic Guidance]] || [[Mohammad Hosseini (politician)|Mohammad Hosseini]] |- | [[Ministry of Defense and Armed Forces Logistics|Defense and Armed Forces Logistics]] || [[Ahmad Vahidi]] |- | [[Ministry of Economic Affairs and Finance (Iran)|Economy and Financial Affairs]] || [[Shamseddin Hosseini]] |- | [[Ministry of Education (Iran)|Education]] || [[Hamid-Reza Haji Babaee]] |- | [[Energy in Iran|Energy]] || [[Majid Namjoo]] |- | [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Foreign Affairs]] || [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] |- | [[Ministry of Health and Medical Education|Health and Medical Education]] || [[Marzieh Vahid Dastjerdi]] |- | [[Construction in Iran|Housing and Urban Development]] || [[Reza Sheykholeslam]] |- | [[Industry of Iran|Industries and Mines]] || [[Aliakbar Mehrabian]] |- | [[Ministry of Intelligence of Iran|Intelligence]] || [[Heydar Moslehi]] |- | [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Interior]] || [[Mostafa Mohammad Najjar]] |- | [[Ministry of Justice (Iran)|Justice]] || [[Morteza Bakhtiari]] |- | [[Labor and tax laws in Iran|Labour and Social Affairs]] || [[Ali Nikzad]] |- | [[Ministry of Petroleum of Iran|Petroleum]] || [[Masoud Mir Kazemi]] |- | [[Transport in Iran|Roads and Transportation]] || [[Hamid Behbahani]] |- | [[Science and technology in Iran|Science, Research, and Technology]] || [[Kamran Daneshjoo]] |- | [[Economy of Iran#Labor and welfare|Welfare and Social Security]] || [[Sadeq Mahsouli]] |} Ahmadinejad announced controversial ministerial appointments for his second term. [[Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei]] was briefly appointed as first vice president, but opposed by a number of Majlis members and by the intelligence minister, [[Gholam-Hossein Mohseni-Eje'i]]. Mashaei followed orders to resign. Ahmadinejad then appointed Mashaei as chief of staff, and fired Mohseni-Eje'i.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jul/27/world/fg-iran27|title=Iran president clashes with conservatives|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=27 July 2009|accessdate=18 June 2011|first1=Borzou|last1=Daragahi|first2=Ramin |last2=Mostaghim}} On 26 July 2009, Ahmadinejad's government faced a legal problem after he sacked four ministers. Iran's constitution (Article 136) stipulates that, if more than half of its members are replaced, the cabinet may not meet or act before the Majlis approves the revised membership.{{cite news|last=Deshmukh|first=Jay |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jYm2jkM3p-MmD8B1Oh9ZDxXNG6xw |title=Ahmadinejad 'sacks four Iran ministers'|publisher=Google|date=26 July 2009|accessdate=7 September 2010}} The vice chairman of the Majlis announced that no cabinet meetings or decisions would be legal, pending such a re-approval.{{cite news|url=http://aftabnews.ir/vdchzinw.23nzmdftt2.html|title=آفتاب – باهنر: جلسات دولت نهم از این پس غیرقانونی است|work=Aftab News|accessdate=7 September 2010}} The main list of 21 cabinet appointments was announced on 19 August 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=104018§ionid=351020101 |title=Ahmadinejad unveils new cabinet |publisher=PressTV |accessdate=18 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918132444/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=104018§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=18 September 2012 |df= }} On 4 September, the Majlis approved 18 of the 21 candidates, and rejected three, including two women. [[Sousan Keshavarz]], [[Mohammad Aliabadi]], and [[Fatemeh Ajorlou]] were not approved by Majlis for the Ministries of Education, Energy, and Welfare and Social Security, respectively. [[Marzieh Vahid Dastjerdi]] was the first woman approved by the Majlis as a minister in the Islamic Republic of Iran.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8235264.stm|title=Iran backs first woman minister|date=3 September 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 November 2009}} ===2012 Parliamentary elections=== Ahmadinejad suffered a defeat in [[Iranian legislative election, 2012|March/May 2012 parliamentary elections]] with Ayatollah Khamenei's "Principalist" allies winning about three quarters of the parliaments 290 seats, and Ahmadinejad supporters far fewer.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/05/world/middleeast/iran-elections-deal-blow-to-ahmadinejad-and-the-presidency.html|title=Elections in Iran Favor Ayatollah's Allies, Dealing Blow to President and His Office|work=The New York Times|first=Neil|last=MacFarquhar |date=4 March 2012|access-date=}} ==Domestic policy== ===Economic policy=== {{See also|Economy of Iran}} In Ahmadinejad's first four years as president, Iran's real GDP reflected growth of the economy. Inflation and unemployment also decreased under Ahmadinejad due to better economic management and ending the unsustainable spending and borrowing patterns of previous administrations .{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2008/03/31/iran-unemployment-idINDAH13987520080331 |title=Iran's unemployment falls to 10.3 pct -minister|agency=Reuters|date=31 March 2008|accessdate=18 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://edition.presstv.ir/detail/106378.html|title=Iran approves plan to lop three zeros off Rial|newspaper=Presstv|accessdate=18 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217073441/http://edition.presstv.ir/detail/106378.html|archivedate=17 December 2013|df=dmy-all}} Ahmadinejad increased spending by 25% and supported [[subsidy|subsidies]] for food and [[petrol]]. He also initially refused a gradual increase of petrol prices, saying that after making necessary preparations, such as a development of [[public transportation]] system, the government would free up petrol prices after five years.Bakhtiar, Abbas. [http://www.payvand.com/news/07/jan/1295.html "Ahmadinejad's Achilles Heel"] Interest rates were cut by presidential decree to below the inflation rate. One unintended effect of this stimulation of the economy has been the bidding up of some urban real estate prices by two or three times their pre-Ahmadinejad value by Iranians seeking to invest surplus cash and finding few other safe opportunities. The resulting increase in the cost of housing hurt poorer, non-property owning Iranians, the putative beneficiaries of Ahmadinejad's populist policies.{{cite news|title=Letter from Tehran, The rationalist|first=Laura|last=Secor |page=31|work=The New Yorker|date=2 February 2009}} The Management and Planning Organisation, a state body charged with mapping out long-term economic and budget strategy, was broken up and its experienced managers were fired.{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/economy/2008/09/iran-economic-ahmadinejad |title=Economics is for donkeys|work=New Statesman|date=11 September 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009}} [[File:Mahmoud Ahmadinejad 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Ahmadinejad at the [[United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development]] in 2012]] In June 2006, 50 Iranian economists wrote a letter to Ahmadinejad that criticized his price interventions to stabilize prices of goods, cement, government services, and his decree issued by the High Labor Council and the Ministry of Labor that proposed an increase of workers' salaries by 40%. Ahmadinejad publicly responded harshly to the letter and denounced the accusations.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Middle-East/2006/Jun-16/72571-iranian-economists-lash-out-at-ahmadinejads-policies.ashx|title=Iranian economists lash out at Ahmadinejad's policies|newspaper=Daily Star|location=Libya|date=16 June 2006|accessdate=18 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/world/2006-09-04-iran-economy-usat_x.htm |title=Geopolitics casts pall on hobbled Iranian economy|date=5 September 2006|first=David J.|last=Lynch|location=Tehran|work=[[USA Today]]|access-date=26 January 2008}} Ahmadinejad called for "middle-of-the-road" compromises with respect to Western-oriented [[capitalism]] and [[socialism]]. Current political conflicts with the United States caused the central bank to fear increased [[capital flight]] due to [[Sanctions against Iran|global isolation]]. These factors prevented an improvement of infrastructure and capital influx, despite high economic potential. Among those that did not vote for him in the first election, only 3.5% said they would consider voting for him in the next election.Sanati, Kimia. [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/IH24Ak03.html "Ahmadinejad held to election promises"]. ''Asia Times''. Retrieved 1 February 2008. [[Mohammad Khoshchehreh]], a member of the [[Iranian parliament]] that campaigned for Ahmadinejad, said that his government "has been strong on populist slogans, but weak on achievement."{{cite news|last=Dareini|first=Ali Akbar|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/17/AR2007011701335.html |title=Iran's Discontent With Ahmadinejad Grows|work=The Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|date=17 January 2007|access-date=28 August 2007}} President Ahmadinejad changed almost all of his economic ministers, including oil, industry and economy, since coming to power in 2005. In an interview with Fars News Agency on April 2008, [[Davoud Danesh Jaafari]] who acted as minister of economy in Ahmadinejad's cabinet, harshly criticized his economic policy: "During my time, there was no positive attitude towards previous experiences or experienced people and there was no plan for the future. Peripheral issues which were not of dire importance to the nation were given priority. Most of the scientific economic concepts like the effect of liquidity on inflation were put in question."{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jPjMFDWR5wix280l0R7irdv5THEg|title=Ahmadinejad slammed by outgoing economy minister|work=AFP|date=22 April 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009}} In response to these criticisms, Ahmadinejad accused his minister of not being "a man of justice" and declared that the solution to Iran's economic problem is "the culture of martyrdom".{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jelVVHDZfukEAiK80qF88B6Q1Tpg|title=Martyrdom would solve Iran's economic woes: Ahmadinejad|work=AFP|date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=21 June 2009}} In May 2008, the petroleum minister of Iran admitted that the government illegally invested 2 billion dollars to import petrol in 2007. At Iranian parliament, he also mentioned that he simply followed the president's order.[http://www.alef.ir/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26085&Itemid=99999999 الف – واردات غیرقانونی بنزین را به دستور رئیسجمهور انجام دادهایم] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018132405/http://www.alef.ir/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26085&Itemid=99999999 |date=18 October 2014 }} While his government had 275 thousand billion [[Iranian toman|toman]] oil income, the highest in Iranian history, Ahmadinejad's government had the highest budget deficit since the Iranian revolution.{{cite news|last=Leyne|first=Jon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7687107.stm|title=Iran economy facing 'perfect storm'|work=BBC|date=24 October 2008| accessdate= 21 June 2009}} During his presidency, Ahmadinejad launched a [[2007 Gas Rationing Plan in Iran|gasoline rationing plan]] to reduce the country's fuel consumption. He also instituted cuts in the interest rates that private and public banking facilities could charge.{{cite news|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=175959 |title=Assembly of Experts to study economic reform plan: Rafsanjani |accessdate=23 August 2008 |date=23 August 2008 |newspaper=Tehran Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912183345/http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=175959 |archivedate=12 September 2008 |df= }} He issued a directive that the [[Management and Planning Organisation of Iran|Management and Planning Organization]] be affiliated to the government.{{cite news|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/06/oct/1192.html|title=Iran: Debate heats up over restructuring of Management and Planning Organization|accessdate=27 April 2009|date=18 October 2006|newspaper=Payvand}} In May 2011, Ahmadinejad announced that he would temporarily run the Oil Ministry.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/05/16/iran.ahmadinejad.oil/index.html?hpt=Sbin|work=CNN|title=Iran's leader taking over Oil Ministry temporarily, news agency says|date=16 May 2011}} ===Family planning and population policy=== {{See also|Family planning in Iran}} In October 2006, Ahmadinejad began calling for the scrapping of Iran's existing birth-control policies which discouraged Iranian couples from having more than two children. He told [[Member of Parliament|MPs]] that Iran could cope with 50 million more people than the current 70 million. In November 2010, he urged Iranians to marry and reproduce earlier: "We should take the age of marriage for boys to 20 and for girls to about 16 and 17."{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2010/1122/Ahmadinejad-calls-on-Iranian-girls-to-marry-at-16 |title=Ahmadinejad calls on Iranian girls to marry at 16|website=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|first=Scott |last=Peterson|date=22 November 2010}} His remarks have drawn criticism and been called ill-judged at a time when Iran was struggling with surging inflation and rising unemployment, estimated at around 11%. Ahmadinejad's call was reminiscent of a call for Iranians to have more children made by Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] in 1979. The policy had increased Iran's population by 16 million in seven years{{rp|321}} but had eventually been reversed in response to the resultant economic strain.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/oct/23/iran.roberttait |first=Robert|last=Tait|location=Tehran|date=23 October 2006|title=Ahmadinejad urges Iranian baby boom to challenge West|work=The Guardian|access-date=11 January 2017}} In 2008, the government sent the "Family Protection Bill" to the Iranian parliament. Women's rights activists criticized the bill for removing protections from women, such as the requirement that a husband obtain his wife's consent before [[polygamy|marrying a second wife]]. Women's rights in Iran are more religiously based than those in secular countries.{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/ebadi-protests-against-iran-s-polygamy-bill/article1-328872.aspx |title=Ebadi protests against Iran's polygamy bill|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|accessdate=21 June 2009}} ===Housing=== {{See also|Construction industry of Iran#Mehr Housing Scheme}} The first legislation to emerge from his newly formed government was a 12 trillion [[Iranian rial|rial]] ([[US$]]1.3 billion) fund called ''"Reza's Compassion Fund"'',{{cite web|url=http://roozonline.com/01newsstory/012137.shtml|title="Reza's Compassion Fund" project archived|accessdate=17 October 2006|work=[[Rooz]]|language=fa |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021113903/http://roozonline.com/01newsstory/012137.shtml|archivedate=21 October 2006}} named after [[Shi'a Islam|Shi'a]] [[Shi'a Imam|Imam]] [[Ali al-Rida]]. Ahmadinejad's government said this fund would tap Iran's oil revenues to help young people get jobs, afford marriage, and buy their own homes.{{cite web|url=http://irannegah.com/Video.aspx?id=593 |title=Video of Imam Reza Love Fund|website=IranNegah.com |access-date=18 May 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306113836/http://irannegah.com/Video.aspx?id=593 |archivedate=6 March 2012 |deadurl=yes}} The fund also sought charitable donations, with a [[trustee|board of trustees]] in each of Iran's 30 provinces. The legislation was a response to the cost of urban housing, which is pushing up the national average marital age (currently around 25 years for women and 28 years for men). In 2006 the Iranian parliament rejected the fund. However, Ahmadinejad ordered the administrative council to execute the plan. ===Human rights=== {{See also|Human rights in Iran}} [[File:Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.jpg|thumb|Ahmadinejad speaking at [[Columbia University]], September 2007]] According to a report by [[Human Rights Watch]], "Since President Ahmadinejad came to power, treatment of detainees has worsened in [[Evin Prison]] as well as in detention centers operated clandestinely by the Judiciary, the Ministry of Information, and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1UbK1st63cgC&pg=PA464&dq=%22Since+President+Ahmadinejad+came+to+power%22,+%22treatment+of+detainees+has+worsened%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi5pI-T6rrRAhXJ7oMKHRRdCt8Q6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=%22Since%20President%20Ahmadinejad%20came%20to%20power%22%2C%20%22treatment%20of%20detainees%20has%20worsened%22&f=false |title=World Report 2007: Events of 2006|author= Human Rights Watch|publisher=Seven Stories Press|date=2011|isbn=9781583229583}}{{rp|464}} Human Rights Watch also has stated, "Respect for basic human rights in Iran, especially freedom of expression and assembly, deteriorated in 2006. The government routinely tortures and mistreats detained dissidents, including through prolonged solitary confinement."{{rp|463}} Human Rights Watch described the source of human rights violations in contemporary Iran as coming from the Judiciary, accountable to [[Ali Khamenei]], and from members directly appointed by Ahmadinejad.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Responses to dissent have varied. Human Rights Watch writes that "the Ahmadinejad government, in a pronounced shift from the policy under former president Mohammed Khatami, has shown no tolerance for peaceful protests and gatherings." In December 2006, Ahmadinejad advised officials not to disturb students who engaged in a protest during a speech of his at the [[Amirkabir University of Technology]] in Tehran,{{cite news|url=http://www.rajanews.com/News/?3739 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307115938/http://www.rajanews.com/News/?3739 |archivedate=7 March 2008|title=گزارش اختصاصي رجانيوز از حاشيه هاي مراسم امروز دانشگاه اميركبير|trans-title=Exclusive report from the margins of today's ceremony Amir Kabir University|website=Rajanews.com |date=7 March 2008 |deadurl=yes|language=Persian|access-date=11 January 2017}} although speakers at other protests have included among their complaints that there had been a crackdown on dissent at universities since Ahmadinejad was elected.{{cite news|last=Fathi|first=Nazila|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/650214386/Students-disrupt-speech-by-Iran-chief.html |title=Students disrupt speech by Iran chief|work=Deseret News|agency=The New York Times News Service |date=12 December 2006 |location=Tehran|access-date=12 December 2006}} In April 2007, the Tehran police, which is under Khamenei's supervision, began a crackdown on women with "improper [[hijab]]." This led to criticism from associates of Ahmadinejad.{{cite news|url=http://www.baztab.com/news/65372.php |title= انتقاد مشاور رئيس‌جمهور از طرح مبارزه با بدحجابي|trans-title=Ahmadinejad's adviser criticizes hijab enforcement issue|work=Baztab.com|access-date=23 April 2007|deadurl=yes|language=Persian|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207120901/http://www.baztab.com/news/65372.php |archivedate=7 December 2008 }} In 2012, Ahmadinejad claimed that AIDS was created by the West in order to weaken poorer countries, and repeated a previous claim that homosexual Iranians did not exist.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/9023777/HIV-created-by-West-to-enfeeble-third-world-claims-Mahmoud-Ahmadinejad.html|title=HIV created by West to enfeeble third world, claims Mahmoud Ahmadinejad |first=Ahmad |last=Vahdat |date=18 January 2012|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=19 January 2012|location=London}} He has also described homosexuality as "ugly".{{cite web|title=Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on homosexualty|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qt_xxqMT2JY|website=YouTube|publisher=CNN|accessdate=14 April 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2012/09/24/president-ahmadinejad-gays-are-ugly-and-are-like-thieves/|title=President Ahmadinejad: Gays are ugly and are like thieves|date=24 September 2012|first=James|last=Park|website=pinknews.co.uk|access-date=28 September 2012}} ===Universities=== {{See also|Higher education in Iran}} In 2006, the Ahmadinejad{{cite web|url=http://www.neyous.com |title=neYous Social Headline News Aggregator |website=Neyous.com |accessdate=2010-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019060335/http://www.neyous.com/ |archivedate=19 October 2010 |df= }} government reportedly forced numerous Iranian scientists and university professors to resign or to retire. It has been referred to as the "[[Islamic Cultural Revolution|second cultural revolution]]".{{cite web|url=http://roozonline.com/01newsstory/016196.shtml |title="Protest against the second cultural revolution." |accessdate=2006-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021111440/http://roozonline.com/01newsstory/016196.shtml |archivedate=21 October 2006 |df= }} Rooz. Retrieved 18 October 2006.Irani, Hamid. [http://roozonline.com/english/016235.shtml "Cleansing in the Name of Retirement"]. Retrieved 18 October 2006. {{Failed verification|date=October 2010}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021093546/http://roozonline.com/english/016235.shtml |date=21 October 2006 }} The policy has been said to replace old professors with younger ones.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftabnews.ir/vdcco4q2boqe0.html |title="Khoshchehreh (MP) protests against the unwanted retirement of university professors." |accessdate=2012-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224051511/http://www.aftabnews.ir/vdcco4q2boqe0.html |archivedate=24 February 2012 |df= }} Aftab News. Retrieved 18 October 2006. Some university professors received letters indicating their early retirement unexpectedly.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftabnews.ir/vdcdnf0yt509o.html |title="Different aspects of the unwanted retirement of university professors." |accessdate=2012-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061004224951/http://www.aftabnews.ir/vdcdnf0yt509o.html |archivedate=4 October 2006 |df= }} Aftab News. Retrieved 18 October 2006. In November 2006, 53 university professors had to retire from [[Iran University of Science and Technology]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927221850/http://news.gooya.eu/politics/archives/2006/11/055304.php "صدور حکم بازنشستگی برای ۵۳ استاد دانشگاه علم و صنعت، ادوار نيوز"] Gooya. Retrieved 26 January 2008. In 2006, Ahmadinejad's government applied a 50% [[Racial quota|quota]] for male students and 50% for female students in the university entrance exam for [[medicine]], [[dentistry]] and [[pharmacy]]. The plan was supposed to stop the growing presence of female students in the universities. In a response to critics, Iranian minister of health and medical education, [[Kamran Bagheri Lankarani]] argued that there are not enough facilities such as dormitories for female students.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Masoud Salehi, president of Zahedan University said that presence of women generates some problems with transportation.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Also, Ebrahim Mekaniki, president of [[Babol University of Medical Sciences]], stated that an increase in the presence of women will make it difficult to distribute facilities in a suitable manner.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Bagher Larijani, the president of [[Tehran University of Medical Sciences]] made similar remarks.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} According to [[Rooz|Rooz Online]], the quotas lack a legal foundation and are justified as support for "family" and "religion."{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} ====December 2006 student protest==== In December 2006, it was reported that some students were angry about the [[International Conference to Review the Global Vision of the Holocaust]], which they saw as promoting Holocaust denial.{{cite web |last1=Theodoulou |first1=Michael| url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/world/protesters-condemn-holocaust-conference-1-733917 |title=Protesters condemn Holocaust conference |work=The Scotsman |accessdate=2016-02-01}} In response to the students' slogans, the president said: "We have been standing up to dictatorship so that no one will dare to establish dictatorship in a millennium even in the name of freedom. Given the scars inflicted on the Iranian nation by agents of the US and British dictatorship, no one will ever dare to initiate the rise of a dictator."{{cite web|url=http://www.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0612111551150517.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929102830/http://www.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0612111551150517.htm|archivedate=2007-09-29|title=President: Students are pioneers of revolutionary movements – Irna}} It was reported that even though the protesters broke the TV cameras and threw hand-made bombs at Ahmadinejad,{{cite web|author= |url=http://peyvast.blog.com/1353199/ |title=Films of yesterday protest in Iran are leaking out « Connections پیوست |publisher=Peyvast.blog.com |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2009-06-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070913232130/http://peyvast.blog.com/1353199/ |archivedate=13 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} the president asked the officials not to question or disturb the protesters.{{cite news|url=http://www.rajanews.com/News/?3737 |deadurl=yes|title= مشروح سخنان بسيار مهم احمدي نژاد در دانشگاه اميركبير|trans-title=Detailed critical remarks of Ahmadinejad at Amir Kabir University|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307115933/http://www.rajanews.com/News/?3737 |archivedate=7 March 2008|language=Persian|access-date=11 January 2017}} In his blog, Ahmadinejad described his reaction to the incident as "a feeling of joy" because of the freedom that people enjoyed after the revolution.{{cite web|url=http://www.ahmadinejad.ir/en/freedom/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430185511/http://www.ahmadinejad.ir/en/freedom/|archivedate=2013-04-30|title=Freedom and Liberty|publisher=Ahmadinejad's English Blog}} One thousand students also protested the day before to denounce the increased pressure on the reformist groups at the university. One week prior, more than two thousand students protested at [[Tehran University]] on the country's annual student day, with speakers saying that there had been a crackdown on dissent at universities since Ahmadinejad was elected.{{cite news |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/650214386/Students-disrupt-speech-by-Iran-chief.html |title=Students disrupt speech by Iran chief |first=Nazila |last=Fathi |work=Deseret News|agency=New York Times News Service |date=12 December 2006}} ===Nuclear program=== {{See also|Nuclear program of Iran}} Ahmadinejad has been a vocal supporter of [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran's nuclear program]], and has insisted that it is for peaceful purposes. He has repeatedly emphasized that building a [[nuclear weapon|nuclear bomb]] is not the policy of his government. He has said that such a policy is "illegal and against our religion."[http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/story/2006/01/060111_mj-ir-nuke-ahmadinejad.shtml "Ahamadinejad: We will reach the nuclear energy in near future."] [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 29 October 2006.[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1078476.html "Ahmadinejad Claims Iran Has 3,000 Centrifuges"] Missile Defense Advocacy. Retrieved 4 September 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217082817/http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1078476.html |date=17 December 2013 }} He also added at a January 2006 conference in Tehran that a nation with "culture, logic and civilization" would not need nuclear weapons, and that countries that seek nuclear weapons are those that want to solve all problems by the use of force.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4613644.stm "Excerpts: Ahmadinejad conference."] [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 29 October 2006. In a 2008 interview Ahmadinejad elaborated that countries striving to obtain nuclear weapons are not politically progressive nations and those who possess them and continually make new generations of such bombs are "even more backward".{{cite news|authorlink=Amy Goodman|last1=Goodman|first1=Amy|authorlink2=Juan Gonzalez (journalist)|last2=Gonzalez|first2=Juan |title=Ahmadinejad: Nukes for not politically progressive states |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=70578§ionid=3510302 |agency=Press TV |date=26 September 2008 |accessdate=26 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926215934/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=70578§ionid=3510302 |archivedate=26 September 2008 }} In April 2006, Ahmadinejad announced that Iran had successfully refined [[uranium]] to a stage suitable for the [[nuclear fuel cycle]]. In a speech to students and academics in [[Mashhad]], he was quoted as saying that Iran's conditions had changed completely as it had become a nuclear state and could talk to other states from that stand.{{cite news|url=http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/060413/2006041301.html |title=Ahmadinejad: Iran can now talk to world from vantage point of a nuclear state |website=ArabicNews.com |access-date=29 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422084214/http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/060413/2006041301.html |archivedate=22 April 2006 |df=}} On 13 April 2006, Iran's news agency, [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] (IRNA), quoted Ahmadinejad as saying that the peaceful Iranian nuclear technology would not pose a threat to any party because "we want peace and stability and we will not cause injustice to anyone and at the same time we will not submit to injustice."{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2006/04/13/AhmadinejadIran-nuke-right-non-negotiable/UPI-84261144938178/ |title=Ahmadinejad: Iran nuke right non-negotiable |publisher=UPI|date=13 April 2006 |access-date=12 June 2006}} Nevertheless, Iran's nuclear policy under Ahmadinejad's administration has received much criticism, spearheaded by the United States and Israel. The accusations include that Iran is striving to obtain nuclear arms and developing long-range firing capabilities—and that Ahmadinejad issued an order to keep [[UN]] inspectors from freely visiting the nation's nuclear facilities and viewing their designs, in defiance of an [[IAEA]] resolution.{{cite web |last=Ravid |first=Barak|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/sources-un-watchdog-hiding-evidence-on-iran-nuclear-program-1.282217 |title=Sources: UN watchdog hiding evidence on Iran nuclear program.|work=Haaretz|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=18 June 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/05/AR2006020500877.html |title=Nuclear Inspections Are Curbed by Iran |work=The Washington Post |first=Ali Akbar |last=Dareini |agency=Associated Press |date=6 February 2006 |location=Tehran |access-date=11 January 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/news/international/countriesandterritories/iran/nuclear_program/index.html |title=Iran's Nuclear Program |work=The New York Times |access-date=}}{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/09/26/mahmoud-ahmadinejad-nuclear-issue-iran-is-now-closed/ |title=Mahmoud Ahmadinejad: 'Nuclear Issue of Iran Is Now Closed' |publisher=Fox News |agency=Associated Press |access-date=11 January 2017}} Following a May 2009 test launch of a long-range [[missile]], Ahmadinejad was quoted as telling the crowd that with its nuclear program, Iran was sending the West a message that "the Islamic Republic of Iran is running the show."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/21/world/middleeast/21iran.html?_r=1 |title=Iran Test-Fires Missile With 1,200-Mile Range |work=The New York Times |first1=David E. |last=Sanger |first2=Nazila |last2=Fathimay |date=20 May 2009 |access-date=11 January 2017}} Despite Ahmadinejad's vocal support for the program, the office of the Iranian president is not directly responsible for nuclear policy. It is instead set by the [[Supreme National Security Council]]. The council includes two representatives appointed by the [[Supreme Leader]], military officials, and members of the executive, judicial, and legislative branches of government, and reports directly to Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]], who issued a [[fatwa]] against nuclear weapons in 2005.{{cite news |last=Recknagel |first=Charles |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1059517.html |title=Iran: Election Of Ahmadinejad Unlikely To Affect Nuclear Negotiations |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]] |date=27 June 2005 |access-date=11 January 2017}} Khamenei has criticized Ahmadinejad's "personalization" of the nuclear issue.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/rest-of-world/Iran-rebukes-its-prez-over-N-policy/articleshow/1319950.cms |title=Iran rebukes its prez over N-policy |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=19 January 2007 |access-date=26 January 2008}} Ahmadinejad vowed in February 2008 that Iran will not be held back from developing its peaceful nuclear program{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/02/23/iran.jealous/index.html |title=Ahmadinejad: Nations jealous of nuclear progress |publisher=CNN |date=11 February 2008 |access-date=11 January 2017}} and has stated that at least 16 different peaceful uses for nuclear technology have so far been identified. Ahmadinejad has stressed the importance of the right to peaceful nuclear development. Iranian opposition leader, Mousavi, has even stated that giving up the country's nuclear program would be "irreparable" and that the Iranian people support the nuclear program. "No one in Iran will accept suspension," Mousavi has said, adding that if elected, his policy would be to work to provide "guarantees" that Tehran's nuclear activities would never divert to non-peaceful aims.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=91361§ionid=351020101 |title=Mousavi: Iran will never halt enrichment |date=14 April 2009 |publisher=PressTV |accessdate=1 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417033036/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=91361§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=17 April 2009}} In October 2009, the [[United States]], [[France]], and [[Russia]] proposed a U.N.-drafted deal with Iran regarding its nuclear program, in an effort to find a compromise between Iran's stated need for a nuclear reactor and the concerns of those who are worried that Iran harbors a secret intent of developing a nuclear weapon. After some delay in responding, on 29 October, Ahmadinejad seemed to change his tone towards the deal. "We welcome fuel exchange, nuclear co-operation, building of power plants and reactors and we are ready to co-operate," he said in a live broadcast on state television.{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2009/10/2009102984633409448.html|title=Iran 'ready for nuclear agreement' – Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera|date=29 October 2009|accessdate=7 September 2010}} However, he added that Iran would not retreat "one iota" on its right to a sovereign nuclear program.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/10/29/us-iran-nuclear-idUSLT25626120091029|agency=Reuters |title=Iran proposes big changes to draft atom deal: report|date=29 October 2009}} ==Domestic criticism and controversies== ===Accusations of corruption=== {{see also|2011 Iranian embezzlement scandal|Iran Insurance embezzlement case}} According to Brussels-based NGO [[International Crisis Group]], Ahmadinejad has been criticized for attacking private "plunderers" and "corrupt officials," while engaging in "cronyism and political favouritism". Many of his close associates were appointed to positions for which they have no obvious qualifications, and "billion dollar no-bid contracts" were awarded to the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]] (IRGC), an organization with which he is strongly associated.{{cite web|url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?id=4647&l=1|title=Iran: Ahmadi-Nejad's Tumultuous Presidency |publisher=International Crisis Group|date=6 February 2007|accessdate=21 June 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709030746/http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?id=4647&l=1|archivedate=9 July 2008}} According to Najmeh Bozorgmehr of [[Financial Times]], "Iran has a long history of cronyism and corruption under its monarchies and the Islamic Republic. But the scale of corruption under Mr. Ahmadinejad was of a different order, according to both reform-minded and conservative politicians."{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/8df9c092-ca2f-11e3-bb92-00144feabdc0.html|title=Iran: Rogue trader|work=Financial Times|date=5 June 2014 |accessdate=20 March 2015}} ===Other statements=== [[File:Vladimir Putin in Iran 16-17 October 2007-9.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Participants of the second Caspian Summit in October 2007. From left to right: President of Azerbaijan [[Ilham Aliev]], President of Turkmenistan [[Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov]], President of Kazakhstan [[Nursultan Nazarbaev]], President of Russia [[Vladimir Putin]] and President of Iran Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.]] In June 2007, Ahmadinejad was criticized by some Iranian parliament members over his remark about [[Christianity]] and [[Judaism]]. According to Aftab News Agency, Ahmadinejad stated: "In the world, there are deviations from the right path: Christianity and Judaism. Dollars have been devoted to the propagation of these deviations. There are also false claims that these [religions] will save mankind. But Islam is the only religion that [can] save mankind." Some members of Iranian parliament criticized these remarks as being fuels to religious war.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/CWN/121605iran.aspx |title="Iran's President Threatens Crackdown on Christianity" |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504173742/http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/CWN/121605iran.aspx |archivedate=4 May 2008 |df= }} ''CBN News''. Retrieved 27 January 2008.{{cite web|date=7 June 2007 |script-title=fa:دفاع از اظهارات احمدی‌نژاد عليه مسيحيت و يهود، آفتاب |url=http://news.gooya.eu/politics/archives/2007/06/060469.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619174926/http://news.gooya.eu/politics/archives/2007/06/060469.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 June 2007 |publisher=[[Gooya]] |language=Persian |accessdate=31 May 2009}} Conservative MP Rafat Bayat has accused Ahmadinejad for a decline in observance of the required [[hijab]] for women, calling him "not that strict on this issue".Harrison, Frances. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6213854.stm "Iran police move into fashion business"]. Retrieved 16 April 2007. Ahmadinejad was also accused of indecency by people close to [[Rafsanjani]],[http://www.ansarnews.com/?usr=news/detail&nid=993 "روزنامه هاشمي": بوسه‌ احمدی‌نژاد بر دست معلم سالخورده‌اش، اشكال شرعي دارد!"] ''Ansar News''. Retrieved 27 January 2008. after he publicly kissed the hand of a woman who used to be his school teacher.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6619077.stm "Ahmadinejad accused of indecency"] BBC News. Retrieved 28 January 2008. ===The UN and football stadiums=== There are two statements that led to criticism from some religious authorities. One concerns his speech at [[the United Nations]], and the other concerns the attendance of women at football matches. During a visit to group of Ayatollahs in [[Qom]] after returning from his 2005 speech to the [[UN General Assembly]], Ahmadinejad stated he had "felt a halo over his head" during his speech and that a hidden presence had mesmerized the unblinking audience of foreign leaders, foreign ministers, and ambassadors. Ahmedinejad closed his speech with a call for the "mighty Lord" to "hasten the emergence" of [[Imam Mahdi]].{{cite news|last=Bruno|first=Greg|title=The Iranian political structure |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+Iranian+political+structure.-a0182127664|accessdate=3 August 2013|newspaper=Iran Times International|date=11 July 2008|location=Washington DC}} According to Iranian-American journalist [[Hooman Majd]], the response given to Ahmedinejad at the assembly was offensive to the conservative religious leaders because an ordinary man cannot presume a special closeness to God or any of the [[Imamah (Shi'a doctrine)|Imams]], nor can he imply the presence of the Mahdi.{{cite book |authorlink=Hooman Majd |last=Majd |first=Hooman |title=The Ayatollah Begs to Differ: The Paradox of Modern Iran |publisher=Doubleday |year=2008 |isbn=0767928016 |page=79}} In another statement in 2006, Ahmadinejad proclaimed (without consulting the clerics beforehand), that women be allowed into football stadiums to watch male football clubs compete. This proclamation "was quickly overruled" by clerical authorities, one of whom, Grand Ayatollah [[Mohammad Fazel Lankarani]] "refused for weeks to meet with President Ahmadinejad" in early 2007. ===Constitutional conflict=== In 2008, a serious conflict emerged between the Iranian President and the head of parliament over three laws approved by the Iranian parliament: "the agreement for civil and criminal legal cooperation between Iran and Kyrgyzstan", "the agreement to support mutual investment between Iran and Kuwait", and "the law for registration of industrial designs and trademarks". The conflict was so serious that the Iranian leader stepped in to resolve it. Ahmadinejad wrote a letter to the parliamentary speaker [[Gholam-Ali Haddad-Adel]], furiously denouncing him for the "inexplicable act" of bypassing the presidency by giving the order to implement legislation in an official newspaper.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/International/Ahmadinejad-under-fire/2008/04/23/id/323501|title=Iran President Ahmadinejad In Rows With 3 Leading Officials |date=23 April 2008 |location=Tehran|website=Newsmax.com |publisher=Agence France Presse |accessdate=21 June 2009}} Ahmadinejad accused the head of parliament of violating Iranian constitutional law. He called for legal action against the parliament speaker.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-press-service.com/ips/articles-2008/april-2008/ahmadinejad-attacks-haddad-adel.shtml|title=Ahmadinejad Attacks Haddad Adel |work=Iran-Press-Service.com |date=April 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=52720§ionid=351020101 |title=Haddad-Adel: Constitution not violated |agency=PressTV |date=23 April 2008 |accessdate=21 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207114200/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=52720§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=7 December 2008}} Haddad-Adel responded to Ahmadinejad accusing him of using inappropriate language in his remarks and letters.[http://www.alef.ir/vdcg3z9x.ak9nt4prra.html?25046 الف – پاسخ رئیسمجلس به رئیسجمهور] ''Alef'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018125358/http://www.alef.ir/vdcg3z9x.ak9nt4prra.html?25046 |date=18 October 2014}} ===Ali Kordan=== {{Main|Ali Kordan}} In August 2008, Ahmadinejad appointed [[Ali Kordan]] as interior minister. Kordan's appointment was heavily criticized by Iranian parliamentarians, media and analysts after it came to light that a doctoral degree purportedly awarded to Kordan was fabricated, and that the putative issuer of the degree, [[Oxford University]], had no record of Kordan receiving any degree from the University.{{cite news|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2008/080815.html |title=Statement: Mr Ali Kordan |date=15 August 2008 |accessdate=17 August 2008 |publisher=The University of Oxford |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817131229/http://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2008/080815.html |archivedate=17 August 2008 |df=dmy}} It was also revealed that he had been jailed in 1978 for moral charges.{{cite news |url=http://www.roozonline.com/archives/2008/08/post_8726.php|title=سوابق اخلاقي|date=14 August 2008|accessdate=14 August 2008|work=[[Rooz|Rooz online]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822005850/http://www.roozonline.com/archives/2008/08/post_8726.php|archivedate=22 August 2008}} In November 2008, Ahmadinejad announced that he was against impeachment of Kordan by Iranian parliament. He refused to attend the parliament on the impeachment day.{{cite web|url=http://www.africasia.com/services/news/newsitem.php?area=mideast&item=081104102917.yxb25ese.php |title=News |work=Africasia |accessdate=21 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207134205/http://www.africasia.com/services/news/newsitem.php?area=mideast&item=081104102917.yxb25ese.php |archivedate=7 December 2008}} Kordan was expelled from office by Iranian parliament on 4 November 2008. 188 MPs voted against him. An impeachment of Kordan would push Ahmadinejad close to having to submit his entire cabinet for review by parliament, which was led by one of his chief political opponents. Iran's constitution requires that step if more than half the cabinet ministers are replaced, and Ahmadinejad replaced nine of 21 until that date.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/03/AR2008110301757.html?hpid=moreheadlines |title=Scandal, Fistfight Erupt Over Impeachment Move in Iran|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=4 November 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009|first=Thomas|last=Erdbrink}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7707963.stm |title=Iran minister sacked over forgery|publisher=BBC News|date=4 November 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009}} ===Conflict with Parliament=== [[File:Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in the Iranian Majlis (1).jpg|thumb|250px|Ahmadinejad speaking in the Majlis, Chairman [[Ali Larijani]] is also pictured]] In February 2009, after [[Supreme Audit Court of Iran]] reported that $1.058 billion of surplus [[oil revenue]] in the (2006–2007) budget hadn't been returned by the government to the national treasury,{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Energy_Resources/2009/02/16/Iran_examines_missing_oil_revenue/UPI-25891234800966/|title=Iran examines missing oil revenue|date=16 February 2009|work=United Press International|accessdate=23 February 2009 }} [[Ali Larijani]], [[Majlis of Iran|Iran's parliamentary]] speaker, called for further investigations to make sure the missing funds are returned to the treasury as soon as possible.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=84719§ionid=351020102 |title=Iran looks into missing $1B oil money |date=5 February 2009 |work=PressTV |accessdate=23 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211131103/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=84719§ionid=351020102 |archivedate=11 February 2009 |df= }} Tensions between Larijani and Ahmadinejad continued into 2013.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/05/world/middleeast/high-level-feud-bares-tensions-in-iran.html High level feud bares tensions in Iran] ''The New York Times'', 5 February 2013 Ahmadinejad criticized the National Audit Office for what he called its "carelessness", saying the report "incites the people" against the government.{{cite news|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/feb/1229.html#s364827|title=Oil Money Report Rejected|date=21 February 2009|work=Iran newspaper|accessdate=23 February 2009}} The head of the parliament energy commission, Hamidreza Katouzian, reported "The government spent $5 billion to import fuel, about $2 billion more than the sum parliament had authorized." Katouzian quoted Iran's Oil Minister, Gholam-Hossein Nozari, as saying that President Ahmadinejad had ordered the extra purchase.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=85792§ionid=351020102 |title=Majlis searching for $1B missing oil money |date=15 February 2009 |agency=PressTV |accessdate=23 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308095614/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=85792§ionid=351020102 |archivedate=8 March 2012 }} In May 2011, several members of parliament threatened to initiate impeachment proceedings against Ahmadinejad after his merger of eight government ministries and the firing of three ministers without parliament's consent. According to the Majles news website, MP [[Mohammad Reza Bahonar]] stated, "legal purging starts with questions, which lead to warnings and end with impeachment." On 25 May, parliament voted to investigate another allegation, that Ahmadinejad had committed election irregularities by giving cash to up to nine million Iranians before the 2009 presidential elections. The vote came within hours after the allegations appeared in several popular conservative news sites associated with supreme leader [[Ali Khamenei]], suggesting the supreme leader supported the investigation.{{cite web |url=http://www.insideiran.org/domestic-relations/is-ahmadinejad-on-his-way-out/ |title=Is Ahmadinejad on His Way Out? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725083453/http://www.insideiran.org/domestic-relations/is-ahmadinejad-on-his-way-out/ |archivedate=25 July 2011 |website=InsideIran.org |date=25 May 2011 |first=Shayan |last=Ghajar |access-date=11 January 2017}} The disputes were seen as part of the clash between Ahmadinejad and other conservatives and former supporters, including supreme leader Khamenei, over what the conservatives see as Ahmadinejad's confrontational policies and abuse of power.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ayatollah-irans-president-bewitched-by-senior-aide/2011/05/15/AF7vOG4G_story.html |title=Ayatollah: Iran's president 'bewitched' by senior aide |first=Thomas |last=Erdbrink |work=The Washington Post |date=15 May 2011 |access-date=11 January 2017}} ===Relations with Supreme Leader of Iran=== [[File:5th International Conference in Support of the Palestinian Intifada, Tehran (1).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ahmadinejad with [[Ali Khamenei]], [[Ali Larijani]] and [[Sadeq Larijani]] in 2011]] Early in his presidency, Ahmadinejad was sometimes described as "enjoy[ing] the full backing" of the [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] {{no selflink|Ali Khamenei}},{{cite news|last=Fathi |first=Nazila |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/07/world/africa/07iht-tehran.4.9063096.html |title=Ahmadinejad loses favor with Khamenei, Iran's top leader |work=The New York Times |date=7 January 2008 |accessdate=18 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629111911/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/07/world/africa/07iht-tehran.4.9063096.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |deadurl=no}} and even as being his "protege." In Ahmadinejad's 2005 inauguration the supreme leader allowed Ahmadinejad to kiss his hand and cheeks in what was called "a sign of closeness and loyalty,"[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2009-08/04/content_8513716.htm Ahmadinejad gets key endorsement as Iran president], ''China Daily'', 4 August 2009 and after the 2009 election fully endorsed Ahmadinejad against protesters.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5576925/Ayatollah-Ali-Khamenei-backs-Mahmoud-Ahmadinejad-in-address-at-Friday-prayers.html Ayatollah Ali Khamenei backs Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in address at Friday prayers], ''The Telegraph'', Damien McElroy, 19 June 2009 However, as early as January 2008 signs of disagreement between the two men developed over domestic policies, and by the period of 2010–11 several sources detected a "growing rift" between them.{{cite news|first=Saeed Kamali |last=Dehghan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/05/ahmadinejad-allies-charged-with-sorcery |title=Ahmadinejad allies charged with sorcery |work=The Guardian |date=5 May 2011|accessdate=18 June 2011 |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110510144655/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/05/ahmadinejad-allies-charged-with-sorcery |archivedate=10 May 2011 |deadurl=no}} The disagreement was described as centered on [[Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei]], a top adviser and close confidant of Ahmadinejad{{cite news |first=Ali Akbar |last=Dareini |url=http://www.stalbertgazette.com/article/GB/20110420/CP01/304209937/-1/sag0806/iranian-lawmakers-warn-ahmadinejad-to-back-intelligence-chief-as&template=cpArt |title=Iranian lawmakers warn Ahmadinejad to accept intelligence chief as political feud deepens |agency=Associated Press |work=StAlbertGazette.com |date=20 April 2011 |access-date=11 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217073724/http://www.stalbertgazette.com/article/GB/20110420/CP01/304209937/-1/sag0806/iranian-lawmakers-warn-ahmadinejad-to-back-intelligence-chief-as%26template%3DcpArt |archivedate=17 December 2013 |df=dmy-all}} and opponent of "greater involvement of clerics in politics", who was first vice president of Iran until being ordered to resign from the cabinet by the supreme leader. In 2009, Ahmadinejad dismissed Intelligence Minister [[Gholam-Hossein Mohseni-Eje'i]], an opponent of Mashaei. In April 2011, another Intelligence minister, [[Heydar Moslehi]], resigned after being asked to by Ahmadinejad, but was reinstated by the supreme leader within hours.{{cite news |first=Geneive |last=Abdo |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/geneive-abdo/clash-over-mashaei-reveal_b_853329.html|title=Clash Over Mashaei Reveals Fissures Within the Iranian Regime |work=The Huffington Post |date=26 April 2011 |access-date=11 January 2017}} Ahmadinejad declined to officially back Moslehi's reinstatement for two weeks and in protest engaged in an "11-day walkout" of cabinet meetings, religious ceremonies, and other official functions.{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0509/Iran-s-Ahmadinejad-survives-worst-storm-of-his-presidency |title=Iran's Ahmadinejad survives worst storm of his presidency |work=The Christian Science Monitor |first=Scott |last=Peterson |date=9 May 2011 |access-date=11 January 2017}} Ahmadinejad's actions led to angry public attacks by clerics, parliamentarians and military commanders, who accused him of ignoring orders from the supreme leader. Conservative opponents in parliament launched an "impeachment drive" against him, four websites with ties to Ahmadinejad reportedly were "filtered and blocked", and several people "said to be close" to the president and Mashaei (such as [[Abbas Amirifar]] and [[Mohammed Sharif Malekzadeh]]) were arrested on charges of being "magicians" and invoking [[djinn]]s. On 6 May 2011, it was reported that Ahmadinejad had been given an ultimatum to accept the leader's intervention or resign,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/06/iran-supreme-leader-ahmadinejad-minister |title=Iran's supreme leader tells Ahmadinejad: accept minister or quit |first=Saeed Kamali |last= Dehghan |work=The Guardian |date=6 May 2011}} and on 8 May he "apparently bowed" to the reinstatement, welcoming back Moslehi to a cabinet meeting.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/irans-ahmadinejad-affirms-khamenei-decision-tensions-remain/2011/05/08/AFpK82QG_print.html |title=Iran's Ahmadinejad affirms Khamenei decision, tensions remain |first=Thomas |last=Erdbrink |work=The Washington Post |date=8 May 2011}} The events have been said to have "humiliated and weakened" Ahmadinejad, though the president denied that there had been any rift between the two, and according to the semiofficial [[Fars News Agency]], he stated that his relationship with the supreme leader "is that of a father and a son."{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/02/world/la-fg-iran-intelligence-20110502 |title=Spy flap weakens Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2 May 2011 |location=Beirut |first=Borzou |last=Daragahi |access-date=11 January 2017}} In 2012, Khamenei ordered a halt to a parliamentary inquiry into Ahmadinejad's mishandling of the Iranian economy.{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/11/2012112119588529396.html |title=Iran calls off Ahmadinejad parliament probe|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=21 November 2012|access-date=11 January 2017}} In 2016, Khamenei advised Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, his former ally with whom his relationship was strained after Ahmadinejad accused his son [[Mojtaba Khamenei]] of embezzling from the state treasury,{{Cite web |url=https://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/01/15/188461.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=18 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826030859/https://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/01/15/188461.html |archive-date=26 August 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} to not run for president again.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/09/mahmoud-ahmadinejad-khamenei-candidacy-letter.html|title=Khamenei puts stop to Ahmadinejad's return|date=27 September 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/middle-east/iran-s-ayatollah-khamenei-blocks-ahmadinejad-s-comeback-1.2807835|title=Iran's Ayatollah Khamenei blocks Ahmadinejad's comeback|work=Irish Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/sep/28/ahmadinejad-blocked-running-iran-presidential-elections-ali-khamenei|title=Ahmadinejad blocked from running in Iran presidential elections|first=Saeed Kamali|last=Dehghan|date=28 September 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://english.aawsat.com/2016/09/article55359128/ahmadinejad-prohibited-run-presidential-elections-based-khameneis-orders|title=Ahmadinejad Prohibited to Run for President...based on Khamenei's Orders|work=Asharq Al-awsat|date=27 September 2016|access-date=1 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018083743/http://english.aawsat.com/2016/09/article55359128/ahmadinejad-prohibited-run-presidential-elections-based-khameneis-orders|archive-date=18 October 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}http://english.alarabiya.net/en/2016/09/26/Ahmadinejad-told-stay-out-of-election.html ===Hugo Chavez's funeral=== Ahmedinejad was criticised by the religious and political groups in Iran for photographs taken of him embracing Elena Frias de Chavez, the mother of recently deceased Venezuelan president [[Hugo Chavez]], at his funeral. In the image, Ahmedinejad was thought to be holding her hands and in a cheek-to-cheek embrace; such an act, touching an unrelated woman, is considered [[haraam]] (forbidden) in Islam.{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/irans-ahmadinejad-under-fire-from-conservative-critics-for-picture-of-him-consoling-hugo-chavezs-mother|work=National Post|title='Lost control:' Iran's Ahmadinejad under fire from conservative critics for picture of him consoling Hugo Chavez's mother|author=National Post Staff and The Associated Press |date=11 March 2013|accessdate=11 January 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/03/11/17272211-ahmadinejads-scandalous-moment-with-hugo-chavezs-mother?lite |title=NBC News, Ahmadinejad's scandalous moment with Hugo Chavez's mother |date=11 March 2013 |accessdate=17 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130314004548/http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/03/11/17272211-ahmadinejads-scandalous-moment-with-hugo-chavezs-mother?lite |archivedate=14 March 2013 |df=}} Iranian government officials responded by stating that the image was a fake, then released a second photo showing Ahmadinejad in the same pose, but in this case hugging a man.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/03/13/opinion/gmez-chavez-ahmadinejad-america/index.html|publisher=CNN|title=Ahmadinejad's hug and the future of Chavez's alliance|date=13 March 2013|accessdate=17 March 2013}} This later photograph was debunked when it was discovered that the other man was Egyptian opposition leader [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], who had not been at the funeral. ===Nepotism=== One of the most frequent criticisms about Ahmedinejad has been [[nepotism]] in his governments. Nepotism was one of his habits in appointing senior government officials.{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad's 'Family Justice'|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Ahmadinejads_Family_Justice/1749454.html|accessdate=28 July 2013|newspaper=Radio Free Europe|date=8 June 2009}}{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Carol J.|title=Iran president-elect hints at need for nuclear sanctions relief |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-iran-rouhani-nuclear-sanctions-20130715,0,7966474.story|accessdate=28 July 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=15 July 2013}} His elder brother, [[Davoud Ahmadinejad|Davoud]], was appointed chief inspector at the presidency in 2005 and was in office until 2008.{{cite news|title=Iran Presidential Election Round Up|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/181567/iran-presidential-election-round/michael-rubin|accessdate=28 July 2013|work=National Review |date=10 May 2009|first1=Michael |last1=Rubin|first2=Ali |last2=Alfoneh}} His sister, [[Parvin Ahmadinejad|Parvin]], served at the presidential's women's center. His nephew, [[Ali Akbar Mehrabian]], served as the mining and industry minister in his cabinet. His daughter's father-in-law, [[Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei]], served at several senior positions.{{cite web|last=Hannun|first=Marya|title=Wait, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's brother is running for president of Iran? |url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2013/05/13/mahmoud_ahmadinejads_brother_davood_is_running_for_president_of_iran|work=Foreign Policy|accessdate=28 July 2013|date=14 May 2013}}{{cite journal|last1=Molavi|first1=Reza|first2=K. Luisa |last2=Gandolfo|title=Who Rules Iran?|journal=The Middle East Quarterly|date=Winter 2010 |volume=XVII|issue=1|pages=61–68|url=http://www.meforum.org/2586/who-rules-iran|accessdate=14 August 2013}} His brother-in-law, [[Masoud Zaribafan]], served as cabinet secretary. ==Foreign relations== {{Main|Foreign policy of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad}} [[File:IRAN PresidentMahmoud AhmadinejadPresidential Trips.png|thumb|Countries visited by President Ahmadinejad during his terms in office]] During Ahmadinejad's tenure as President of Iran the foreign policy of the country took a different approach from the previous administration. Relations with [[developed country|developed countries]] generally soured while relations with [[Developing country|less-developed countries]], including Africa and Latin America, rose. In light of the calls for sanctions on Iran for its nuclear weapons programme, Ahmadinejad and his foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, traveled extensively throughout the two regions, as well as hosted other leaders. Relations with the [[Bolivarian Alliance for the Americas|ALBA]] states, and [[Venezuela]], [[Bolivia]], and [[Ecuador]], in particular, were most strengthened. Relations with America during the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]] and Israel deteriorated further. Ahmadinejad is an outspoken critic of the [[Western world]] and is often criticized for his hostility towards the [[United States]], [[Israel]], the [[United Kingdom]] and other Western nations.{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Ahmadinejad-blames-West-for-AIDS|title=Ahmadinejad blames West for AIDS|publisher=Associated Press |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=29 July 2008}}{{YouTube|QW1DltEt5z4|President Ahmadinejad, Part 2}}, [[CBS]] ===Israel=== {{main|Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Israel}} [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Azerbaijan 18 November 2010-4.jpeg|thumb|right|Ahmadinejad with leaders of the Caspian sea bordering nations]] Ahmadinejad abides by Iran's long-standing policy of refusing to recognize [[Israel]] as a legitimate state, and wants the Jewish people who immigrated to Israel to return to their "fatherlands" (''translated'').{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/meast/04/24/iran.nuclear/index.html?_s=PM:WORLD |title=Iran president says UN sanctions unlikely |publisher=CNN|date=24 April 2006}} In 2005, Ahmadinejad, in a speech praising the Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khomeini, was translated by Iranian state-run media as saying that "Israel must be wiped off the map."[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927213903/http://www.iribnews.ir/Full_en.asp?news_id=200247 "Ahmadinejad: Israel must be wiped off the map"], IRIB News, 26 October 2005.{{cite news|last=Nazeela|first=Fathi|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/27/world/middleeast/irans-new-president-says-israel-must-be-wiped-off-the-map.html |title=Iran's New President Says Israel 'Must Be Wiped Off the Map'|work=The New York Times|date=27 October 2005}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4378948.stm |title=Iran leader's comments attacked |publisher=BBC |date=2005-10-27 |accessdate=2015-07-22}} A controversy erupted over the translation, with specialists such as [[Juan Cole]] of the University of Michigan and Arash Norouzi of the Mossadegh Project pointing out that the original statement in [[Persian language|Farsi]] did not say that Israel should be wiped off the map, but instead that it would collapse.{{cite news |last1=Kessler |first1=Glenn |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/did-ahmadinejad-really-say-israel-should-be-wiped-off-the-map/2011/10/04/gIQABJIKML_blog.html |title=Did Ahmadinejad really say Israel should be 'wiped off the map'? |work=Washington Post |date=5 October 2011 |accessdate=2015-07-22 }}{{cite news |last=Friedman |first=Uri |url=http://www.thewire.com/global/2011/10/debating-every-last-word-ahmadinejads-wipe-israel-map/43372/ |title=Debating Every Last Word of Ahmadinejad's 'Wipe Israel Off the Map' |work=The Wire |date=2011-10-05 |accessdate=2015-07-22}}{{cite news|last=Steele|first=Jonathan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/jun/14/post155|title=Lost in translation|work=The Guardian|date=14 June 2006}} The words 'Israel', 'map', and 'to wipe off' are non-existent in the Iranian speech's original. According to another IRNA translation, on the occasion of a commemoration of the anniversary of Khomeini's death on 3 June 2008, Ahmadinejad stated that "The corrupt element will be wiped off the map."{{cite journal|authorlink=Katajun Amirpur|first=Katajun |last=Amirpur|url= http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/15700607-201200a6 |title=Iran's Policy towards Jewish Iranians and the State of Israel. Is the Present Iranian State Islamofascist? |journal=[[Die Welt des Islams]]|publisher=BRILL|volume=52|issue=3/4|year=2012|page=387}} Contextually, Ahmadinejad was quoting Khomeini's words about the imminent disappearance of the Soviet Union and the Shah's regime, and tacked on his remarks concerning Israel. In [[Katajun Amirpur]]'s analysis, there is no implication in the text that Iran intended destroying Israel or annihilating the Jewish people, any more than Khomeini was suggesting with his words that the Russians, or the Iranian people themselves under the Shah would be extinguished. Ahmadinejad is on the record as stating that Iran had no plans to attack Israel. The statement itself was in fact a citation, with a minute verbal variation, of a remark made by Ayatollah Khomeini in 1979, which had created no furor at the time, but did so when Ahmadinejad quoted them in 2005.{{cite book|first=Eric |last=Hooglund|chapter=Decoding Ahmadinejad's rhetoric on Israel|editor-first1=Eric |editor-last1=Hooglund|editor-first2=Leif |editor-last2=Stenberg|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YNzFBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT206 |title=Navigating Contemporary Iran: Challenging Economic, Social and Political Perceptions|publisher=Routledge |year=2013|pages=198–206}} [[File:Lula e Ahmadinejad 2010.jpg|thumb|left|Ahmadinejad meeting with former [[Brazilian president]] [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] in [[Tehran]]]] [[Dan Meridor]], Israel's minister of intelligence and atomic energy said during an [[Al Jazeera]] interview that Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had repeatedly said "that Israel is an unnatural creature, it will not survive. They didn't say, 'We'll wipe it out,' you're right, but, 'It will not survive.'" adding "If Iran says this, and continues to pile up uranium that they enrich, and build missiles in big numbers, and have a nuclear military plan—if you put all this together, you can't say, they don't really mean it."{{Cite web|url=http://www.israelhayom.com/site/newsletter_article.php?id=3984|title=Meridor: Ahmadinejad didn't say, 'Wipe Israel off the map'|date=17 April 2012|website=Israel Hayom|access-date=}} The Washington Post's fact-checker editor Glenn Kessler says the interpretation gets murkier when Ahmadinejad's quote is set against other Iranian propaganda. Karim Sadjadpour, an Iranian specialist at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, cites proof that the Iranian government releases propaganda that clearly says Israel should be "wiped off." Joshua Teitelbaum of the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs discovered pictures of Iranian propaganda banners that clearly say in English: "Israel should be wiped out of the face of the world."{{cite news |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/17/israeli-minister-agrees-ahmadinejad-never-said-israel-must-be-wiped-off-the-map/?_r=0 |title=Israeli Minister Agrees Ahmadinejad Never Said Israel 'Must Be Wiped Off the Map' |work=The New York Times |date=17 April 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/did-ahmadinejad-really-say-israel-should-be-wiped-off-the-map/2011/10/04/gIQABJIKML_blog.html |title=Did Ahmadinejad really say Israel should be 'wiped off the map'? |work=Washington Post |date=4 October 2011}} In March 2016, Iran tested a ballistic missile painted with the phrase "Israel should be wiped off the Earth" in Hebrew. The missile is reported to be capable of reaching Israel.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/03/09/reports-iran-fires-missiles-marked-israel-must-wiped-out/81517488/ |title=Reports: Iran fires missile marked with 'Israel should be wiped' |first= |last=|work=USA Today |date=9 March 2016 |access-date=}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/15/world/middleeast/iran-israel-un-missile-tests.html |title=Israel Calls on U.N. to Punish Iran for Missile Tests |date=14 March 2016 |work=The New York Times |first= Rick |last=Gladstone |access-date=}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/440377/iran-nuclear-arms-dangerous |title=Unthinking the Thinkable: Iran and the Bomb |website=National Review |first=Spencer |last=Case |date=26 September 2016 |access-date=}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/iran-ballistic-missile-test-launch-nuclear-deal-israel-middle-east/ |title=Iran tests missile capable of reaching Israel |publisher=CBS News |agency=Associated Press |date=9 May 2016 |access-date=11 January 2017}} The Official Web site of the [[President of Iran]] quoted Ahmadinejad as saying on 15 May 2011 "The reason for our insistence that the Zionist regime should be wiped out and vanished is that the Zionist regime is the main base for imposing oppression and harbors the main terrorists of the world."{{cite web|url=http://www.president.ir/en/28177 |title=President Calls Zionist Main Terrorist Hub in World |accessdate=2015-02-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722225325/http://www.president.ir/en/28177 |archivedate=22 July 2015 |df= }} Access date 2016-07-30. Both this link and the corresponding Farsi page have been removed from the official web site of the Iranian President. The Farsi original has not been re-discovered.
